reviewText:
I have already put over 50 hours in on Xbox One and just bought this version a few hours ago. My thoughts? VERY much worth it to any DBZ fan, anyone else should wait for a price drop.

Pros:

Amazing storyline. Although not written by Toriyama himself, but rather Dimps, it follows true to the Dragon Ball heart. It stays close enough to what has been presented before so that it remains believable and memorable, but strays just enough to keep you on your toes to see what happens next. Ends up in an ending that is neither overly impressive nor unimpressive, just satisfying.

Large selection of characters. While Base/2nd/3rd form Frieza and base/2nd form Cell are missing, along with characters like Dabura and Androids 16, 19, and 20 (Gero), they still have plenty of characters to choose from, all of them feel unique in their own ways.

Character creation. Not as immersive as some games have it, but you can change your race, gender, hair, facial features, voice, and name. While your character doesn't typically speak outside of yelling attack names, these changes presented are still nice, with enough for them to improve upon in future sequels.

Amount of content. I've played over 50 hours and still have yet to do everything the game has to offer, and I've yet to start the DLC. Grinding for the next move you want or to get the Dragon Balls remains ever fun, training with mentors to learn new skills, and playing through the story as well as battling with friends and taking on quests with people from around the world, the game gives plenty for you to do.


Cons:

Simple battle system. You have light attacks, heavy attacks, ki blasts, 4 swappable Special Moves, 2 swappable Ultimates, and a single swappable Evasive skill. It leaves a lot to be improved upon in future releases, though is passable.

Controls. You'll probably want a gamepad, as the k/m controls are, while functional, a bit awkward. Not deal-breaking IMO, but if you're planning on using your trusty keyboard and mouse, you'll need to get used to the inputs.

Limited options. You can change the resolution, framerate, motion blur, and anti-aliasing, but that's about it. Better than Naruto, but not as good as some big release PC games.



Overall, great game geared towards fans of Dragon Ball Z.

You're actually in control and if you're a DBZ fan, this is exactly what you've been waiting for. The story? Something new and exciting. I won't say any more than that due to not wanting to spoil anything, but it's new. Not to mention, it isn't something you're going to beat in a single sitting. And you can make a female Buu which is waifu of the year easy.

Everything about this game is just.. WOW! The custom characters, the skills/clothing, the combos, the story, the side quest.. Just all of it.

If you are a Dragon Ball fan it's a must have, either way this is the best fighting game of this generation so far.
10/10

reviewText:
I'm a huge fan of Dragon Ball, and I've played a number of the games since Budokai. I bought this week one in excitement for the release. I've played the game to storyline completion, and completed almost half of the PQs so far. I've generally enjoyed it, but frustrations are building and I'm no longer certain this was a good purchasing decision.

PROS:
+Customer characterization is cool! You can play as multiple character races from the series, including Frieza-type aliens. Customization allows for specific builds which employ moves or skills from multiple DBZ characters, allowing for an interesting fusion of styles. There's a variety of cool costumes that call back to even the most obscure (such as an outfit Bulma wears on one Dragon Ball manga cover, Arale from Dr. Slump's hat, and the hats Goku and Krillin wear when they attend their first Budokai Tenkaichi).
+Control scheme is simpler and more approachable to those who may not be as experienced with the DB fighting games.
+There are new, original characters for the game's storyline, including the Supreme Kai of Time and Demon God Demigra.
+In the multiplayer lobby, you can goof around by doing hilarious character poses, like the Ginyu Force poses, or Great Saiyaman's entirely too elaborate poses.
+At its strong points, combat feels great, with the exaggerated sound effects, combos, and dramatic camera angles adding a lot of excitement, reminiscent of the show.

PROBLEMS WITH ONLINE PLAY:
Online play is a complicated, fickle beast. There's a lot of problems here.
-First, you have to play online unless your internet connection is off. There's no offline option within the game settings. It will always log you onto the servers. This can be aggravating when there's a lot of server downtime. It can take a long time for the game to boot because it spends a while connecting to the server. Even in single player lobby, if the servers go down, you'll be booted from play and have to log back in.
-Connections can be very unstable. Characters lag across maps and sometimes freeze in place, or enemies don't spawn in. Sometimes the quest will simply freeze upon completion, until one character forcibly closes the entire game. Often, one or more participants will not receive credit, experience, money, or items upon completion. While grinding for items with friends, this can be very frustrating. I am doubtful that this is entirely to blame on my internet connection speed, and feel that measures could've been taken to deal with the issue.

OTHER CONS:
-Item droprate is utterly brutal. Some equipment is purchasable for large sums of zeni in the in-game store. However, some of the more desirable equipment must be unlocked via Parallel Quest. The problem is that it's highly specific and randomized. Quests have secret requirements in order to unlock extra battles or equipment within them. There is very little information to go off of within the game as to what these requirements are (sometimes context or character relationships could provide insight). Sometimes, when you do fulfill these secret requirements, the battle finishes early anyway. And if you do complete the requirements, you still have a random chance of getting the item. This can be extremely time-consuming if there's a particular look or build you're trying to create for your character.
-The difficulty curve can be awkward at times. Computer AI can vary from relentless to completely ignorant. One battle, I might get stunlocked into a corner, another, I might be able to stand next to my opponent and freely charge to super saiyan without so much as a single glance in my direction.
-Some design elements feel cumbersome and purposeless. You are required to walk to whatever game option you want to play. While the idea of Tokitoki City is nice in concept, in execution, it results in players taking one to two minutes to select play options as opposed to seconds. While grinding for item drops, this can cause a lot of annoyance (though the distance is shorter to the PQ desk).
-Sometimes characters can become stuck on objects, forcing players to either end the game in the lobby, or accept a KO in matches.
-Some gameplay mechanics aren't explained to the player, resulting in some early game confusion.

I'm hoping that the developers will consider a number of the major issues, which have been vocalized numerous times by the community, and work to improve this game so that it can achieve its potential. For now, I would advise against most from purchase, though avid fans who are willing to look past problems may find themselves enjoying the highlights.

DISCLAIMER: I'm not fan of DB universe, only read the manga so wont be talking about the lore in the game.
Who doesn't love fast paced combat? Well.. if you dont like it move along because Dragon Ball Xenoverse is all about fast paced combat and incredible effects!
Story

The story might be the weakest part of the game(writing-wise, else its quite well executed for what it is) . Someone is rewriting the history and you need to stop them but first you need to set history on its normal course which means that you gonna take part in big fights from the manga/anime. There are cutscenes in both anime(2D, trying to make you nostalgic) and in-game(3D) style. The story is quite short(I needed 6 hours to beat it)  but in between each Saga you can do side quests to level up. By doing story missions you unlock masters and side quests to bother with later on.

Gameplay
Here comes the important part of the game.

Combat

Combat is Faaaaantastic. It almost grasps the feeling from the manga... apart from the long charging scene filled with useless dialogues... there is none of it...  but the fast paced action is there to stay.
During fights you have 4 basic attacks : normal and heavy attack, range attack and throw attack(combo from guard and range) . You can also dash from danger, then you have 4 super attacks that can be ki bursts,strikes(physical attack), transformation,power ups and other" . If you decide to save up Ki you can use ultimate attacks which often are varietion of super attack but stronger. At at the end there is 1 last skill slot for evasive moves. I used controller and didnt really made sense to me to have 7 skills and having 1 empty button. 8th skill could be for transformations but thats only my opinion.

At times combat may feel repetetive(only if you make it so) because you may end up doing same combo over and over again until you change your skill set.

Your own Avatar

The game lets you make your own Avatar in DB universe(you can still play as other characters if you unlock them). Creator isnt that great imo but still does the job just fine. You can change height body
recommended:
skin and such but the variety isnt big. There is even voiceover but yet to hear my character say a word.

Gear up and consumables

In the game you can wear different kind of clothing and can even try to make yourself to look like your favourite character. Sadly the clothing is bind to different playstyle so you either pick your skills first or your clothing and work from there.
Also a bummer is that not all clothing can be dyed the way you want so you may end up just like everybody else.
You have 4 clothing slots(top

reviewText:
TLDR: The biggest problem with the game right now is the servers.  There are some drawbacks in the gameplay department but the pros outweigh the cons.  If you're a fan of the Dragonball series and the world that Akira Toriyama has created then this game is a must buy.  If you don't really care for Dragonball but are interested in the gameplay it is a solid game but packed with fan service that will probably go over your head.  You will also probably be less forgiving of its flaws and may not get enough enjoyment out of the story and the Dragonball world to offset them.   Character customization is definatley the high point of the game, everything from looks to stats to skills is up to the player.

Long review:

If you like the Dragonball universe and the past Dragonball games then there's a great chance that you'll love this game.  There's a ton of fan service here for those that know the story well.  There's also a nice refreshing take on the old story with a new Time Patrol twist.  Your character feels like they belong in the Dragonball universe and they become important to the story of the Xenoverse game.  With the way they did the story it feels like your character is an important part of the Dragonball history and not just some voiceless, tacked on nobody that you get to customize.

The customization is great too.  Being able to choose between human, namek, saiyan, maijin or changeling is a great start and there's a variety of body builds and looks that you can use to personalize your DB avatar.  It probably isn't the most in-depth character creation you've ever seen but it offers enough variety for you to individualize your avatar.  Each race starts with it's own unique bonuses.  Namek's, for example, get natural regen when their health is low.  Saiyans get a bonus to offense but have lower health than other races, etc...

You'll get to dictate what skills are available to your character by earning them through quests or by choosing a mentor.  Your mentor will be a well known character from the Dragonball universe, they include heroes and villains, and they will give you quests to complete in exchange for learning their skills.  After you've mastered one set of skills you are free to move on to the next mentor (or, if you don't like the skills you're getting, you can select a new mentor at any time).  If you want to be a Maijin who goes Kaokenx20 and then blasts people away with Piccolo's special beam cannon, Krillins destructo disc and Vegeta's final flash all in one match, you can.  Feel free to change it up in-between fights as often as you see fit.

You'll also have control over your stats.  Your character will receive 3 attribute points each level to put into Health, ki, stamina, basic attacks, strike supers (which are physical super attacks) and ki blast supers (which are energy attacks) up to a max level of 80.  It's completely up to you what your character will excel in.  You can specialize in ki blasts and have weak physical attacks or vice versa.  Or you can try to be well rounded and do a little bit of everything.  It's completely up to you.

When you finish up the main quest line you'll have access to 55 Parallel Quests with a wide range of difficulty.  Each quest has a random chance to drop skills, items and gear relative to the difficulty and the characters that appear in the quest.  Your reward will be directly related to how well you perform and you'll be given a score that ranks your performance from D at the low end up to Z at the high end.  You can choose to do these offline with NPC teammates or online with other players.  You'll also gain access to pvp battles ranging from 1v1 to 3v3.  This is all in addition to the main quest line which can probably last you anywhere from 10-15 hrs depending on how adept at fighting games you are.  You can easily put 40-60 hours into your first character.

There are some cons.  Right now the biggest con is the server stability.  Sometimes multiplayer is great, sometimes it's completely broken and you can't log in at all.  The game is also a bit grindy.  If you're unlucky you can spend a whole day grinding for an item in the same Parallel Quest over and over again and never get it.  You're also going to run into hackers who are giving themselves godlike stats to cheese you in pvp, but what game doesn't have this problem to some degree?  Very rarely, I've had missions where an enemy npc will get stuck in a mountain, where they aren't supposed to be and I have a hard time getting to them to KO them and finish the quest.  This problem hasn't occured but maybe 2-3 times in 56 hours of gameplay for me.

There's a really good amount of content in this game and for those of us that just want a Dragonball world to get immersed in and be a part of this game will somewhat scratch that itch. The pros outweigh the cons, in my opinion, and there is enough game here to play offline if you absolutely had to to make it worth the $50.00.  More than likely in the worst case scenario, you would be unable to log into the Multi-Lobby"
date: which is a hub city where you can meet players and form teams.  You would probably still be able to queue up for online Parallel Quests with other players and online battles in a single lobby (a hub city populated by npc's that you can recruit to help with quests) but without the multi-lobby it is a bit harder to keep track of the people that you want to play with again.\n\nOverall this game is still worth the time and the price even if it does have some flaws at the moment.  If you aren't the biggest Dragonball fan and really don't know the story or care for the DB universe too much then I would suggest holding off.  The drawbacks will probably be a lot more difficult for you to forgive if you're not into Dragonball in the first place.  If you're a fan of the series and know the story like the back of your hand then the new "Time Patrol" approach is a nice refreshing take on a very familiar story.  The game is a grind but doing the same quest over and over for gear isn't so bad when your character is so versatile and customizable.  Part of the fun for me is changing up my skills as I acquire new ones to figure out what works best (and you can do this as much as you want in-between quests).  So even if the scenery doesn't change for a bit

reviewText:
TL:DR at the end!
I do like this game but there are some things you should definitely be aware of if you consider buying it. But let's start from the beginning.

Character Customization:
Do not rush it! Check out builds and guides to choose which race and gender fits your playstyle. Your first character is the most important because it takes a really long time to unlock the other slots. You can delete the character and all skills and items you got so far will be saved but it would still be a waste of time.
The cosmetic customisation has some variety. You can definitely create something more or less unique...or werid.
The part where the customization truly shines is the skill-system. There is a massive amount of skills and equitment that will make you character unique. Sadly the skills aren't well balanced.
Most gear isn't dyeable. Only the starting gear and some high-end Sets.

Tutorials:
I personally found the tutorials to be bad. I had to figure out most of the controls myselfe wich brings us to the next point.

Controls:
They have their flaws especially in close-combat but you should get used to minor issues. Controller is strongly recommended! But overall it's easy to learn unless you want to memorize some insane combos.

Online:
Connecting takes way too long. Some people like to call it an mmo-something. It is not! Between Battles you are walking around in an interactive Lobby called Toki Toki City. If you have an internet connection and chose Multi-Lobby you will see other people running around as well. (but not blocking your path) You can recruit them to fight with you as NPCs. If their level is above yours you have to pay for it. This also works in offline mode but only with NPCs integrated by the developers.
You can battle with or versus other people. Beware of lags! I mean serious lags! Most people you will encounter will have lvl 80+ characters so make pvp with friends at the beginning or just wait for your character to become strong enough.

Port:
Yes, it's not the best port but not the worst either. Toki Toki city is seperated in 3 areas. 4 if you count the time-thing. These areas should be one for pc-users in my opinion. Every pc that can run this game should be able to run the whole city at once without loading screens.
The inventory isn't really sortet. There are ways for mouse and keyboard to make it way better but i guess the developers really wanted us to play with a controller anyway.

Story:
I don't like it! For me it feels like the developers were looking for a way so you can have a custom character AND replay battles from the series. Well it worked but the story around it feels forced. The battles are still fun even if some of them feel unfair and maybe 1 out of 30 jokes was funny!
The Storymode has no co-op!

Paralell Quests:
These are sort of sidemissions you can complete with 2 NPCs or 1-2 players online. As rewards you can get skills, outfits, playable characters, items, dragonballs,... Well nearly everything in the game comes from Paralell Quests!
Paralell Quests are usually fun but if you're going for a specific skill or item you may throw your PC out of the nearest window. Some things just have an insane, luck based droprate. Wanna farm that item? Do that Quest 40 times!
Dragon Balls also take a lot of farming but if you're trying to grind your way to level 100 you will have more than enough.

Leveling:
Every time you level up you'll get 3 Skillpoint. That means you'll have a total of 300 Skillpoints to invest IF you rech level 100. With 300 points you can max out 3 stats. If? It takes FOREVER! As soon as you hit level 85 you will curse the developers for how asian the amount of exp you need to level up becomes!

Gameplay:
So far i pointed out a lot of not-that-great-stuff but now it's time to praise the game!
The gameplay is really fun! Making your own character in the DB-Universe to fight with or against well knows characters from the series is a unique Experience. The combat is fast and you will often rely on muscle memory for making combos. Each build is it's own experience more or less. Each fight has little, unskippable cinematics (without lip-sync) that might be a little annoying if you repeat the stage for the 10th time. But those are usually about 3 seconds long so not a big downside. Usually they are like *character appears* I will totally defeat you even if you killed me x times before!".

Mentor/Master System:
Very early in the game you can get a Mentor. Those are original Characters from the DB Series who will teach you skills and sometimes give (and sometimes demand) items. You fight them first. Then you make a lot of story/paralell quests to get to the next stage and fight again. Repeat this three times and you've completet a Mentor.
There are two downsides. First Mentors spawn randomly in Toki Toki city. If you look for Cell for instance that means you might have to restart a game a few times before he appears. The other downside is the time it takes to get from one stage to another. It's not too bad if you grind for stuff anyway but it still gets annoying.

DLC:
O-V-E-R-P-R-I-C-E-D-! Yes
date:
they add content to the game. Short content that does in no way justify the price.
If you really like the game and finished the story you may buy the Season Pass but that's your decision.

TL:DR:
Dragon Ball Xenoverse is a well made fighting game that requires a lot of time to put into repetitive things.
The Story isn't well written but fun to play and if you always wanted to make yourselfe a fat

reviewText:
It's nostalgia bait, but it's executed in the very best way. Being able to put your own custom made character into the Dragon Ball story is the cherry on top.

The combat, while fairly simple, is actually fun, fast, and very responsive.  The ability to have 3 on 3 fights in a large arena where you can fly around in is awesome.  The character customization also allows for you to equip moves and ultimate abilities from other Z fighters at any time outside of combat.

Keyboard controls are awkward, but it works great if you have an Xbox (or similar) controller.

There is also a small element of exploration in which you can search for items in the arenas, these can be used for crafting in your hub world.  While not necessary, since you can just buy said items, it helps to do that to save money for the large variety of clothing and accessories available for your character.  Most of which change your stats in some way.

Overall this game has a lot of content for the player to unlock.  And a lot of bang for your buck.

Before I go into the bad, the only other thing that I can say that makes this game purchase sort of iffy is the difficulty wall.  It's easy enough up until you beat Freiza, but then after that there's definitely a skill wall that you need to climb up.

The bad thing about this game is the awkward interface and hub world.  For example, it's really awkward to have a 2 player offline fight.  You need to sign in, and then pick your character, then run through the hub world to the npc that'll allow you to do this.  There's no way to pick it from a menu at the title screen.

The other  bad thing I can say about this game is that, at the time of writing, the online mode is completely broken. Often getting disconnected even while playing in single player.

Overall this game is really nostalgia, combat and loot system could use a little work :)

reviewText:
Infuriating RNG on loot and too laggy to play with anybody online properly. Most of the PVP players have moved onto playstation anyways, leaving the PC version practically deserted. The gear your character can equip has an effect on your stats, MANY of which contradict the very characters they are based on. Such as Piccolo and Bardock who're straight Blast type characters having outfits that weakens Blast type moves.

The game was a decent attempt to bring us something new to the franchise. A new story, two new characters and the ability to create our own. But many things in the game needed to be double checked before release (such as the gear's effects) or even completely removed (such as the RNG and gear stats all together).

The only reason this game was said to take 100 hours to complete was because of the RNG on loot drops. I'm here months after release and still haven't gotten everything. Not because there is so much to get, but because the game refuses to give me my rewards. I've lost track of how many times I've played the same mission over and over, only for it to not drop what I want.


The final DLC attempts to fix the RNG problem with a Z Soul that dramatically increases your chance to get loot drops. Unfortunately, you have to be level 93+ to train with Elder Kai and max out his training before you can get it from him, and that takes a LONG time to achieve. Level 99 is the max and it takes like 60 or something PQ's to max out training with a master. By the time you even get this Z Soul, you've probably beaten the game, reached max level and have grinded so many times you've grown bored by this point!

Also making people pay money for a better chance to get loot in the form of DLC was not cool.

reviewText:
The dodge and guard systems still are not as polished as Burst Limit was, but I don't know if it will ever get back to that level of precision.

That being said, this game is a blast!

You can design your own unique character, get wished into existence by Shenron, and go around history fighting historic (series canon) battles or paralell (alternate reality) battles that happen during the course of DBZ timeline. Overall, this game is a standout and unique experience within the DBZ universe compared to most DBZ games that just rehash parts of the series.

After completing the entire storyline and close to half of the side missions, the skill sets are varied, and you can build a truly unique character as far as abilities. (Kamehameha / Short range masenko / Final flash, and a destructo disc barrage on one character for example).

The only complaint I have is that every DBZ game I have played besides burst limit has handled the dodging mechanic in a rather poor way and this one is no exception.

reviewText:
This is the first Dragonball game I've played since Budokai 3 back on PS2. It has that fun feel with rpg elements such as leveling, and character building. I won't bother with a detail review as others have done before me.

Pros:
Lengthy storyline, Follows events after GT. I'd recommend watching Battle of The Gods.
Lots of different things to do, many different set ups to try out.
As you beat Time Patrol, you unlock new Parallel Quests which can be used to grind or for exp and items. Personally i made frequent use of the DLC missions once i caved, and purchased the season pass.
Decent graphics, awesome soundtrack.
Lots of different characters+variations of those characters... everything from classic Goku, Saibamen, Freeza's underlings, Cell Jr to Broly.

Cons:
Online is prone to hackers, don't bother with the leaderboards. Fight with your friends for fun instead.
Camera is glitchy as hell, especially in the Space arena. This can make or break some missions. Many Ultimate Finishes require you to do them within a certain time, and when the camera spins as you dash toward an opponent it can waste time, same goes for traveling to locations within a mission.
Lag - The game CAN at times be considerably laggy, even on local play.

If you are a Dragonball fan, despite the cons i mentioned for $50 you get what you pay for.  It is a decent game and much better then what got released for the PS3 titles. I do recommend the Season Pass. If you are unsure if you like the newer Dragonball games, wait for a sale. I also recommend an Xbox 360 controller or gamepad of your choice.

reviewText:
First Impressions:

Let me just start off by saying I'm definitely one of those 90s kids who grew up with Toonami and all that, so the nostalgia factor has been pretty intense from the moment I started the game up with Cha La Head blasting.  I'm not a DBZ fan in particular, but I did enjoy it.  I picked this up during the sale because I don't mind grindy, MMO-esque games, as long as they're vibrant and fun to play.  So far I'm not disappointed, but I can imagine if you're a fan of the hardcore DBZ fighting games that this might not be up your alley, since combat feels fairly simple once you take your lumps in the first few missions.

The most appealing aspect was being able to make my own character in the DBZ universe, and there's a decent amount of options for the races they offer.  You can change armor and even armor color later pretty effortlessly, too.  They're all presets however, no sliders here, so that may be an issue for some.  Your race matters too, and some characters will take note of just who you chose to be.

The world hub has some convenience flaws, like not being able to dash to get to where you're going faster.  You're given some decent preset motions and texts to interact with others, which helps bring your character alive a bit more outside the story's cutscenes.  It's a bit confusing at first as nothing is unlocked and you're vaguely told to go talk to everyone.

Controller support is good, but I'm using a DS4 and the game insists on thinking I have a numbered gamepad instead of showing the buttons for a 360 controller, which is easier to translate in my head.  Once you learn what's what it's fine, but makes learning a bit difficult if you're a player who's going to be using a Dualshock.

Running on a 970 on Windows 10, no framerate issues at all or tearing after I turned v-sync on.  Everything looks crisp, bright, and shiny.  Music's good quality and clear, voices are.. fairly what I'd expect, for better or worse haha.

So far, it's definitely a recommend if you're coming in expecting a fan experience, but not some groundbreaking, amazing game.

Updated impressions @ Lv. 50:

Definitely leaning more toward recommending only if one is a DBZ fan.  The atmosphere and experience do make up for a lot of the flaws and some odd design choices, like slipping in super hard Parallel Quests in the lower tiers where it seems like the enemies never stop coming.  Frustrating stuff.  Combat gets a lot smoother as you power up and learn, but the game really does not hold your hand at all through the process of learning about armor, stats, and builds so you can succeed.  Being able to preview gear before you buy it would have been a welcome feature as well.

Took me about 14 hours to get through the story with some Parallel Quest grinding.  Lots more replayability than just those hours of course, as there are still characters and places I have yet to encounter.

reviewText:
I'll get my gripes out of the way first, then onto my overall thoughts!

Audio - I want to be able to pick separate devices for voicechat (headset) and in game sounds (speakers). currently people in my group just have to put up with hearing the tv noise, and I have to try and udnerstand them over explosions and such. Meh.

Hair! - There should be a hair style shop to let you change your hair. I leveled to like 20 before I started getting tired of my hair and wanted to change it up, had no means to do so.

No costume preview - when buying new costume parts, It's a real bummer that you can't preview how the item looks before comitting to buying it.

Overall:
I'm loving this game, it's awesome that there is finally a robust character creation system in place and people can band together to make their own personal teams. The single-player storyline is something I would expect to see in the show, it fits right into the DBZ universe seamlessly. The original antagonists and ally characters fit right in and are written pretty well. Long story short, playing this game makes me feel 13 again!

Combat:
Honestly I picked it up right away, without much experience in the other DBZ titles out there, and it was intuitive andresponsive enough that I got the hang of it quickly. I like that powering up takes a skill slot, so not everyone can do it. Changing one move out in your skillset makes a huge difference in how you play.

Customization:
Lots of races to play as, lots of options to pick from! A huge part of the game is playinc missions to collect coins which you can spend on costumes, accessories, and moves to use. So customization is a huge part of it.

reviewText:
It's a Dragonball Z MMO done right, something people have been trying to imagine for years and it's finally a reality. An absolute must for any fan of Dragonball Z, anyone who has played previous Dragonball games and enjoyed them, or for people who just like to beat the sense out of someone before they can even blink.

You can either create your own character from the five playable races they have available or play as one of the many well-known characters from Dragonball Z, Dragonball GT, and even characters from some of the movies (some need DLC). Customize the way you fight and put together your own set of iconic moves; from Death Ball to Instant Transmission, this game has pretty much everything.

The story is pretty original as far as Dragonball goes and it's pretty cool to have characters like Frieza, Cell, and even Goku as your training master. They can teach you their powerful signature moves you can utilize to destroy anyone who so much as looks at you wrong.

You can even invite people to help you out on missions; so team up with a friend to take on the challenges, or fight them one on one for sport. Trust me, hilarity will insue.

There's also a crafting system, because what MMO doesn't have one right? On top of that you can buy new clothes and costumes to make the hero or villain you envision, or to just look like one of the canon characters instead to confuse everyone around you.

So if you're looking to buy Dragonball Xenoverse, I fully believe this game is definitely worth the asking price.

reviewText: My Playthrough          Youtube Playlist                 The Review        This is a game that I have been waiting for. I was a huge fan of Dragon Ball Z as a kid and I have always enjoyed playing the Dragon Ball Z: Budokai games so of course I was excited for a PC Dragon Ball game that allows you to create your own character. And I can tell you that this game is worth the wait. This game has a great fighting mechanics as they are easy to learn and very fun.The graphics are very nice and fits the art style nicely. But the biggest draw for me is the story. We finally game a DBZ game with an original story. Going though the original DBZ timeline and seeing it change and offer new possibilities was very enjoyable. The voice acting was also good but I wish my created character actually spoke some lines of dialogue. Why choose a voice for my characters if they don't speak to people. While this game has a lot of pros it also has some cons. One major con is that the online multiplayer is somewhat unbalanced with some characters being way to overpowered. But since they are still updating the game at the time of this review, I hope that they balance the game more.  In conclusion, rather you are a DBZ fan or not, you will have fun with this game.

While I still enjoy the game, it's not acceptable for servers to be like this on release. Still a good game and playable without the online but if I can't access features of a game on release that's just terrible. So I take what I said about online back for now, will update when servers are fixed.\n\nDragon Ball games on home console have not been that great recently, but with Xenoverse brings us a decent console Dragon Ball game (don't ask me about the ps3 and 360 versions though) and for the first time a PC Dragon Ball game! reviewText:
Pretty great game. It's definitely a fighting game at its core, as big glorious DBZ fights are front and center of the gameplay, but there's also some RPG elements spliced in. At the start you make a custom character (the game has a pretty good character creator all things considered) that's worked into the main plot of the game. You gain levels and distribute points into six different attributes that can benefit your preferred play style. Characters can also be further outfitted with different items, equipment, and attack skills. The majority of the game between fights takes place in an MMO-esque hub world where you can progress through the main plot, do side quests, fight online/with friends, and buy/sell/trade items. It's a strange thing to get used to, especially if you're coming from more traditional fighting games, but it works pretty well for the most part.

The game itself looks and runs great on PC, which I was surprised at. It seems to be well optimized with a good number of graphics options and support for a wide range of controllers as well as keyboard/mouse controls. The only issue I've run into is reliably connecting to the game server, sometimes you get randomly disconnected or it takes a good while to log in. Hopefully it's something that can be ironed out soon.

Overall though it's a pretty fun and addicting game, definitely one of the better DBZ fighting games out there. Highly recommended, especially if you're a long time fan of the series.

reviewText:
After playing quite a bit this is definitely a game to own if you're a fan of the series or even of fighting games in itself. There are plenty of things that make this game a top tier game for the rpg elements of leveling and skill points, mentor system to learn from 12 masters, the story plot and the replayability it offers.

Pros:
Character creation-Very robust character creation, plenty of races with their own stat boost and unique properites along with a multitude of voice options and other appearance options.

Story-Something every fan wanted was a good story and you to have some relevance to it, not like Ultimate Tenkaichi did in a way that was a cliche alternate universe that existed at the same time as the other. You feel like you can make an impact and although your character doesn't talk you still feel like you're there because of how they react to you.

Skills-The sheer amount of super moves and ultimate moves is staggering, want to be all ki based? Easy, want to be all melee based or have a balance? No problem, the amount of variety is suffocating and makes not knowing what cool moves to have in your arsenal that much tougher.

Cons:

Difficulty-There is only one setting for difficulty and it's just a global wide setting, enemies scale in a way that it's not needed and forces you to go do time patrol quests to level up accordingly every few stories or else you'll get pummeled by being underleveled.

Graphics-The graphics are not bad at all in any way but feel slightly outdated, perhaps in a way due to shading which may be due to last gen limits and not pushing the boundary on pc's but it does mean that you don't need a super computer to play on max settings at least.

Parallel Quests-These can get really repetitve after having to spam one mission over and over to get everything out of a certain stage, but they do offer respite from spamming the story or are great to play with friends if you want to spam the really hard missions and fail and laugh with each other about it.

Slots: You only start with one character slot and can only create one at the beginning until you get more at a later point in the game.

End Results: 9.9/10

Other than the repetitive nature of the parallel quests I have thoroughly enjoyed this game a lot, more so than I expected which was already a high level. It's been awhile since I have had so much fun and I easily think anyone who's a fan of the series or even rpg/fighting games in general will have a blast with this easily. Expect great moments and tough moments of close encounters of fighting the tough characters.

reviewText:
Xenoverse is the only DBZ game I've owned. I've played a few of the fighters at friends', and an RPG or two on emulators.

It's a very flawed ARPG. There are omissions of characters and mechanics that are kind of sore for me. Transformations like Kaio-ken and Super Saiyan are an understandable difficulty to balance in a multiplayer game, but are nevertheless unsatisfying to me. The necessity of grinding for items/skills to flesh out a character would only be a hassle if you didn't need to level up your character to even approach the missions that yield the good stuff. Having to grind to get to the grind is a pain and a half. Not to mention that the drops are random.

That said, I am having a ball with it. Most of all, putting together a character, dressing it up nice, and wandering around the Multi-Lobby like its an anime convention. Enjoying Xenoverse is a lot like enjoying the Dragonball franchise: I'm disappointed at every turn because I love it so much.

reviewText:
I would have to say that this game is worth every penny of the price.

It is a DBZ game that has RPG elements as you can gain XP and level up your character that you create yourself. You gain points to put into different stats such as basic attacks, energy blasts, supers, health and stamina.

The story is a completely new story within Dragonball, it uses both the original story that we all love and adds a ton of new ideas and concepts to it such as time travel, making certain foes within the DBZ timeline more powerful then they used to be and by allowing your character to fight alongside iconic characters within the DBZ World.

The game runs awesomely on PC, I was worried that it would be a butchered port of a console version of the game, however it does seem that this was also made with the PC in mind throughout development so kudos to DIMPS for that.

However I do have a few issues with the game as nothing is perfect. The first being the difficulty: The game starts off easy enough, however about an hour into the game, it becomes punishing. Not so that you can't win but you do have to think about how you are going to fight. Later on the game becomes even harder but if you train enough (level up and gain points for stats) you can win any fight with some challenge.

Sorry for the long winded review! This game is awesome in every respect!

reviewText: The game has its share of problems, but it is still a pretty fun game. One main thing I have a problem with is even though you try to play offline single player mode, it still has to log in to the Xenoverse servers. Which as of right now are not working properly. I'm either stuck at the server loading screen until I force quit, or I get to play one level and it boots me out of the hub area. I did however get to play it extensively when it came out. The fighting is very similar to Budokai Tenkaichi, but seems slightly less complex. Still a better fighting system then recent DBZ games, but it can get a bit repetitive. The hub area is very big, which makes getting around a bit annoying. There needs to be a run button or some kind of quick travel to get around better.  The character creator is a plus. There are all kinds of things to choose from for your race, hair/alien head shape, sizes, eyes, and colors. There are also tons of clothing to earn or buy, to deck out your own character. Lots of fighting moves to earn and buy also. It also has a RPG like status system, Though I don't know what a few stats even do. They did not go over what each stat does in the tutorial. The game starts off a little slow, but picks up  after a few missions. Though the game has some issues that need to be addressed, it is still a entertaining DBZ game. So if your a fan or enjoy the games then add this to your collection. I'm gonna hope that time will fix most issues with patches.

reviewText:
I have played this game both on xbox 360 and PC with a total of over 100+ hours and can say it is an awesome game!

First you begin fighting the almighty Frieza, then you move onto Perfect Cell and finish defeating the indestructible Buu but that is only the beginning of this journey of a game.

The things you get in this game are cool and worth the you get many ways to customize your character such as skill points, clothing, race and gender. Story line is awesome because it is a little different from many of the previous Dragon Ball games and has a cool twist to the end. Parrelel quests are a good feature, it adds a whole lot more content to the game and cool drops so you can repeat the same quests waiting for a skill or a piece of clothing to drop. I also find that the fact you can change your characters skills into being an all melee type badass to a Kamehameha blasting maniac gives the game a lot of variation in terms of what you want your character to be, also choosing the right race with the right stats can give you a massive boost of power in battle.

I would say the things to improve on this game is more options for your character such as more hairstyles, I would like to have more hairstyles such as Raditz's and Vegeta's style, the ones we get for them are pretty lame as almost everyone in DBZ has a cool looking hairstyle and we get these  Also a nerf on the character's skills would be nice as when I like to go pvp you get people maxing out everything into one stat and you get 1 combo'd with melee attacks or an ultimate skill which is not that fair or fun in my opinion.

Other than that this game is good if you are a dragon ball fan or even if you are not a fan pick it up and within a week you could be sat there watching the whole Dragon Ball series! This is the first game I have picked up of the Dragon Ball series so I can not compare it to any others but this being my first game I was blown away when I first got in and was fighting frieza

Well where do I start with this game...

Nostalgia I suppose...

I was on the edge whether I wanted to buy this game or not. Really was on the fence about it. It looked awesome... but it could get boring fast, and then a friend gifted the game to me. Here I am 10 hours into the game STRAIGHT after downloading it.

Hell yeah its freaking FUN. Mashing all those buttons as a Z-Fighter fighting all those villians. It's an awesome feeling. The game seemed to run at solid 60 fps which is a good thing! Usually a japanese game like (something like monster hunter) would be locked at 30fps. Even the new DQ warriors would be 30fps locked. A plus for this game!

Co-op

The game has a simple co-op function. You could join a lobby filled with other players and take on quests together. It worked flawless if you're in the same region. Although I played with someone from EU, the latency was quite bad but the you could still fight just fine (well a couple of misses here and there because of the lag)

Overall I'll give this game 8/10

Its really fun. Get it with your friends and SAVE the history of dragonball from being ruined! (oops minor spoiler there).

reviewText:
Amazing to finally have a Dragon Ball game on Steam, and I like many others on steam hope it is one of many to come. However this review will not be quite as glowing as the other reviews as I‚Äôm going to give the developer‚Äôs some tough needed love on certain aspects of the game.

Gameplay and Story:
Gameplay is overall excellent, you can start by making your own character from the the different races that been ‚ÄúMajin, Saiyan, Human, Namekian, Freezer‚Äôs Clan‚Äù apart from the last two each has Female and male and the game has just enough slots for each type of character and gender for you however you must first beat the game to unlock all the slots. From my playing and findings I find each class to have its own uniqueness to them however in my honest opinion you just can‚Äôt beat a good Saiyan, specially one who knows Super Saiyan 2 and certain moves, as they naturally have the strongest strength and Kai averages making them very powerful and can be even more powerful with the boots such as going super.

The game consists of 3 major gameplay implementations, the story that is okay, its accommodated by some nice cut scenes at certain points of the game like the Anime however I noticed the frame rate of those cut scenes to be noticeable and low but it was just cut scenes that were enjoyable. Most of your time you will find yourself doing PQ short for Parallel Quests, these are the side quest that you must do to grind for items (and when I say grind I mean, chuffing grind for them) and grind for levels specially at the later stages and finally your online PVP system that is sadly plagued with hackers at the time of writing this.

One of the finest parts of the game is getting the gear and new moves, getting the get up you want really makes it Fashion Ball Z but is regardless an integrated part of connecting to your character. The best way to think of this game is a very strong solid pillar of what to support, however as your hours of the game start to delve into it deeper you start to see the support structures holding it up are a bit weak and or lazy in many areas.

So moving onto some negatives on the Gameplay; The tutorial is basically non-existent, the game did tell me how to grapple an enemy but I soon forgot and it was half of the game before I relearnt it to deal with touch enemies, normally I would have look at the Skill list to learn all the moves, sadly it doesn‚Äôt exist, if it does I have not found it. There is a Skills List but all it says is ‚ÄúY X X X‚Äù for combo basically, that‚Äôs it and this is very disappointing as if you want to Master combat and haven‚Äôt played any of the games say since Budokai Tenkaichi 2 and 3 you are going to be left perplexed, I still don‚Äôt know how I do a vanish chase but sometimes I do and sometimes I don‚Äôt.

Another flaw I must mention is the hub you spend your time in the game, it‚Äôs a little too big and empty and after you beat a PQ it puts you right at the pods and you must walk all the way back to the PQ area to get another or do the same one again, this is just lazy, put me back or give me an option to pick another or retry.

Graphics:
Nothing much can be said about the graphics, they are decent and nice looking, the game itself runs perfectly fine however I have one graphical bug that sometimes the Ki moves show, and sometimes they do not. Some fixes fix this temporarily so waiting for a patch from Nvidia or the developers to resolve this.

Overall I loved the many hours I have already put into this game, I never thought I would like a Dragon Ball game again since Budokai Tenkaichi just because the wish the combat system was like those games as they were perfect but Xenoverse does a great job at nailing this combat even with the lack of proper Skills List that I won‚Äôt hold my breath for.

Overall I give the game a 7/10, harsh love has to be dealt to learn from mistakes but would recommend this game to hard core fans such as myself as it is very enjoyable when you take a small blind eye to the flaws.

Pros:
-	Lot of content such as items and fighting moves
-	Good combat system
-	Nice graphics
-	Combat is fast and at time hectic

Cons:
-	Lazy corners were taken with the support of the game
-	No proper Skills List
-	Lazy spawning and making it awkward and time consuming for the PQ
-	Some bad voice acting in the Story, all mainly from trunks

reviewText:
Dragon Ball Xenoverse... the name is... odd, to say the least. However what lays under Xenoverse's strange title, is a game that I'd awaited for literally, years.

My personal history with Dragon Ball games goes back to the early 2000's, playing SNES rom's of the fighting games and RPG Super Saiyan Legend. As well as the Playstation 1's Ultimate Battle 22 and Dragon Ball Z Legends.  Of course, Xenoverse has more in common with the later Tenkaichi games than with say, Ultimate Battle 22 [which is of course a great thing.]

The prior game in the series that even comes close to Xenoverse gameplay wise, is Ultimate Tenkaichi, which was released for the PS3 and Xbox 360. Where Ultimate Tenkaichi had a relatively minor create a character ability, allowing one to create a custom male saiyan, Xenoverse throws it to the wind, and gives us a full host of 5 races, 3 of which have 2 genders, and each has different, underlying stats. Xenoverse offers up the ability to create Majin's [buu's race], Saiyans, Humans, Namekian's[only male], and Freeza's race [only male, and named Freeza Race].

These create a characters are the bread and butter of the game frankly. With a host of customization options, including super moves, ultimate moves [the big attacks], and various clothing pieces, scouters, swords, ect. You're able to create damned near anything you want, from re-creating a character that may not be in game from Dragon Ball lore, to your own special snowflake super saiyan 2 god.

The combat in Xenoverse is about the level of the prior Tenkaichi games, with some refinement in my opinion. The controls feel good and the camera decent, while wonky in some aspects, leads Xenoverse to be a fairly fun action fighter.

However, not everything is sunshine and rainbows in DBZ land. Apon launch, Xenoverse saw a huge influx of players, that the developers and publisher had no idea was going to hit numbers far exceeding the ability of the servers to handle.  While this was remedied in a fairly timely fashion, Lag is a continual issue in online battles. Speaking of online battles, the Multiplayer of Xenoverse is, especially on PC, full of hackers. With the decision to house player data locally, players have been able to utilize various cheating tools to give themselves outragious statistics [100 in everything, which is impossible.] As well as access characters and content not even available to the average player. And god mode hackers have been seen topping the leaderbords in PVP.

The other shortcoming of Xenoverse lays in it's loot system. Which awards you on a pure RNG system. You could play the same mission 20 times and get Raditz boots half of that time, and never see his chest piece. As an example. And while this isn't a huge issue, for those of us who wish to get complete sets of gear, it does tend to be rather tedious, especially when some things don't trigger properly, or are not explained in the most helpful of ways. And even if you trigger the ultimate win conditions, you could STILL not get the item you're attempting. And be awarded nothing but XP.

Despite Xenoverse's Shortcommings. Dragon Ball Xenoverse is a solid entry in the long line of DBZ 3rd person fighters, that has it's roots in the Tenkaichi series over all others.  All that's holding Xenoverse back, is a relative lack of some playable characters, and a rather tedious RNG system that seems almost punishing at times. However, the storymode is solid for a DBZ title, and the customization is decent for the first major title with customization.  I have to give them points also for, well, offering this iteration up on PC, as this is the first Dragon Ball title, outside of the now defunct Dragon Ball Online, to have been offered up on PC.

Dragon Ball Xenoverse rates a solid 7/10 in my book. A damn fine dragon ball z game, but lacking as a game on the whole. Despite that it's a solid game that's worth the buy.

reviewText:
Before I even review the game I want to point out something important.
This is the first Dragon ball Z game to be released on PC in years (About 10 years give or take)
That alone is enough of a reason for you to buy it.
Why you may ask? Because the second game developers and publishers understand that it's popular here as much as it is on console (they can make money from us PC gamers),then every new game will also be released on PC as well.
Think about the Naruto ninja storm games. They released 3 for PC, and it turned out to be a big success. They also released Revolution on PC alongside the console releases as well.

In short support this PC/Steam release DBZ game for future titles for the master race.

Now for the actual review.

As a person who has had the chance to play most of the modern Dragon ball Z games to date.
I'd say Xenoverse is AMAZING.
Granted it does have it's flaws, but it does try to be different in a good way, and it has succeeded.

reviewText:
I'm going to recommend Xenoverse to you, anonymous reader. But before you rush toward the purchase button, please read through my criticisms and ask yourself- are any of these issues deal breakers? If you're a fan of Dragonball, they probably will not be. If you are not a fan, well... Read on.

The hub world, Toki Toki City, has a fair share of issues. Not having an option to move faster in town is kind of irritating, especially when you need to visit several locations. This is exacerbated by the fact that the game already has quick move controls. Being dropped half a map away from the parallel quest desk after each one you take part in is a serious drag. If we could get that changed out, that'd be great. There isn't much to do in Toki Toki City overall, which is really too bad because it's interesting visually. I feel like they could have mashed it all into one or two sections and have lost very little. Maybe they figured they needed the space for players to meet up?

The battle system is hardly flawless either. Control seems a bit sloppy, and comboing is unintuitive- I keep kicking the air behind me when I instinctively try to mix up a combo. Fighting multiple enemies is a pain well beyond the measure it ought to be, even when you're several levels above your targets. Combat is very much about being more powerful than your opponents, and not enough about beating them out through skill, which dissapointed me. Though I've heard talk of counters and such, the tutorial is NOT clear enough on this point. Speaking of the tutorial, a mention of how to use items during it would have been nice. I got through the Cell stage before I learned how to use them.

The designed character seems pretty weak too. Your avatar being a 'mute' with no personality is rather disappointing. The option to pick an overall personality (cocky, cowardly, brave, rowdy, exciteable, possibly others) and giving them a few lines based on it would have been nice. Instead you only get to hear certain attack names. The only ones I've heard my character use are Kaioken and Masenko, though I haven't used many, and have not made it very far into the story. Also, I created a female saiyan, and while the other characters recognize my race just fine, she has been addressed as though she's a man on multiple occasions. It breaks the immersion pretty bad. Also I was pretty disappointed when I found that equipment has an effect on stats- I would sooner have kept it entirely cosmetic, so I could pick and choose what bits of outfit to wear without it affecting my capabilities in battle- Especially considering how hard it seems to be find sets that boost atk and beams at the same time.

All that said, I'm having a lot of fun with it despite the flaws. Landing supers and ultimates is satisfying, and the story is fresh even to long time dragon ball fans. There are lots of skills and items to discover as well, so there's a lot to do. But really, I'm just glad I didn't drop nearly $80 on another Ultimate Tenkaichi!

reviewText:
Short Pro/Con Summary

Pro:

+Decent graphics.
+Decent gameplay.
+Storyline is OK if you like the DB Universe.
+Several multiplayer modes to choose from.
+Char custamization.
+Game runs smooth. (excluding the network issues)
+Trading cards
+Archivements

Cons:

-To many hackers (Having all stats maxed out, already moving before battle starts etc...) in multiplayer.
-Still some gamebreaking bugs for multiplayer. (Players losing in ranked battles just shut down the game and terminate connection to the servers, so that they won't lose points...)
-Publisher taking no actions against mentioned issues above.
-Server Issues (DCs, Lags etc... but seems like it got better after they upgraded the servers)
-Storyline only playable once. (You can replay the story like doing other side quests, but there is no real playthrough again)
-Quests are just repetative.....
-No difficulties to choose from in Single or Co-op game. ( All in all the game is to easy)
-No VAC (critical in my eyes if a game is depending on playing online)
-No original japanese language avalable (In my opinion original language should always be avalable in any game.)
-Limited to 7 skills to equip (4 Super,  2 Ultimae and 1 Evasion skills). Could be few more in my eyes to secure a wider variety in your fighting style.
-The ingame chat it rather useless than usefull. Only good for saying HELLO
-Ingame mechanism to find friends or other players is rather broken...

Impression:

About the gameplay, it feels more like an action-simulator rather than a real action game. The combat itself looks speedy if you have checked out some videos, so you might think you will be very busy while playing that game, but that's not right.
It will be more like this. You have to press a certain button combination (mostly left or right trigger button + any of the buttons A,B,X,Y on your gamepad) to start 1 of those 7skills that your char has equipped, then you can relax for the next 2 to 5 secs (sometimes up to 10secs) while your character is performing that action.
Of course in real it won't be that relaxing, since your char might get disturbed while performing his action, but compared to other fighting games like Street Fighter, Tekken or DoA, you won't be that busy in DBX.

The singleplayer story is short (still enjoyable for 1-2 days) and just a joke that you can play through the storyline only once. (You are able to replay it like the other side quests, but you won't have that feeling of a storyLINE again, like when you play through it on your first time). You are only able to play through the story with your own created custom character. So it might happen that you face some problems at some point of the story, if you care less about optimazing your characters attributes.

So what else can you do then, especially in endgame? You could do the same parallel quests either online or offline over and over again, at least that's 1 of the few options you got. If you want to own every avalable skill or skin in this game, I guess you have to do it anyways, since you will get the most of those items and skills rewarded  by the end of the stages as a random drop. But it also feels like grinding over and over again in a typical MMORPG nowadays. Easy to imagine how it will get boring from day to day.......

So, the only real content you have in endgame are the muliplayer PVP matches, where you can choose between ranked and non ranked matches. In non ranked matches you have the choice of 1 on 1, 2 on 2 and 3 on 3. The ranked fights (if you win you earn points, if you lose you lose points) are all 1 on 1, and these can be pretty fun. I my self enjoyed it a lot, and woul'd have enjoy it even more if there wasn't some problems...

A big problem in this multiplayer is the massive amount of cheating players. If this game would'nt have all that hackers and all those bugs (some were fixed by now , but there are still enough critical ones left), it would be a decent pvp action/fighting game. But sadly it seems that Bandai Namco is taking no action against all those people.
So, this ranking points makes no sense at all, since you can have a win streak against 5,6 fair playing players to earn some points, just to lose those points to someone who plays with activated hacks etc...)
And just a short look on that ranking table is enough to see, that some people even hack their points...

(*seems like a weeks after this review was originally written, the amount of cheating players in multiplayer is decreasing, but still they are present and no actions taken against them by the publisher)

Well anyways, in my eyes, it was just an expensive lesson for me to learn that you should never buy a game again thats focusing on online playing and that has no VAC implemented. At least I will be carefull in the future if there is no VAC and the game depends heavily on online playing.

So if it's just about DBX as a game, I woul'd rate it as a positive game. But unfortunately, combining it with the community and the lack of support by the publisher for those players trying to enjoy the game, is forcing me to give it a negative rating.

So, no recommandation from my side.

*I think $29,99 USD would be a fair price for this game.

reviewText:
As taken as I am with Dragon Ball Xenoverse, I don't believe I can recommend it to anyone but fans of the Dragon Ball series. For those people... I can't recommend it highly enough.

The graphics are perfect (It really does feel like playing an episode of Dragon Ball Z), the combat is, for lack of better summary, excellent, the story was incredibly well done (Historical battles are faithfully represented, cut scenes closely mimic the manga, timeline alterations are tasteful and fit well), and Cell's voice acting is at least 30% better than in the TV show.

Now that's all well and good, but the avatar creation and character customization take the cake. Placing your hero alongside the Z Warriors is pure, concentrated childhood wish-fulfillment. The feels you'll feel the first time you go Super Saiyan are hard to describe, but fall somewhere between Boner-rific" and "Worth the price of admission".

$50 is a small price to pay to go Super Saiyan. You do want to be a Super Saiyan

date: and there is some degree of strategy involved.\n\nThis is a phenomenially fun game. In my opinion

reviewText:
I have to say for being new to Dragon Ball video games in general, I would say this game has such great gameplay and highly addictive fighting system of what I have currently played. When I first got the game, I had felt some regret of buying since the games of Dragon Ball Z going downhill, I believe that I'm just going to play one of them for the first time and hate it. Yet, This game proves me and my friends wrong with it's incredible opening, RPG Elements, Storyline (Which I have to admit is quite interesting for a change) and the fighting system that I mentioned earlier.

+ RPG Elements adds purpose to fighting in the new quest system as well as the Story, giving you experience for your fully-customizable character (Which I forgot to mention that is interesting since you can choose from 5 different races to support your playstyle of your wish.)

+ Addictive Fighting System which allows you to form combos in a fast-paced combat along with super abilities that will deal huge amount of damage to your opponents, There is also the transformation system which is not as depth as the other games, but can support you against strong opponents such as Frieza (Which I have to admit that I struggled against for some time)

+ 3V3 is awesome, it adds more depth to the combat whether you are fighting with computers or other players, supporting your allies with different kind of skills while the fighting the opposing team.

+ Martial art Tournament I don't know much of at the current moment due to it not being open yet, but I bet It's gonna be fun.

+ Hercule and Videl are Playable, I like those two characters from the series and I am happy to be able to play as them in this game.

+ First time on PC, Dragon ball has been said to never have a game on PC before and this seems pleasing for a computer game.

+ Story is something new and wish not to spoil it due to it being different, but I have to say it is interesting.

- Has some bugs in certain places which very rarely bother me from time to time

- Short Roster which has good reasons of why it's short

- Required to grind alot to fight strong opponents and consumes a lot of time (Don't recommend game to those who want to get to level 100 quickly because it's takes a long time to get there)

My final score for this game is a 8.4 out of 10 due to some of the cons, but I recommend this game to fans of the series New or Old.

reviewText:
An absolute triumph for the Dragon Ball fighting games. This was everything Budokai had dreamed of being.

2v2, 3v3, and an online overworld running rampant with tons of completely unique players, all friendly and fun to play with. AND it's not just limited to battles, either! Parallel quests are like side quests of the main missions, but the difference is that you can do them with 3 people! and they can be at different parts of the map, making it really fun to try and see who can get the best speeds and run-times on these missions, as you can really get tactical there

The items and unlockable movesets in the game are extensive, even more so than Budokai 3.

The servers have been spotty for me, but I really doubt it's the same for everyone, and seeing it is launch day for PC I'm not upset. The server disconnects me ever couple of battles or so, but I've remained online doing things for a solid 2-3 hours before, so I'm not concerned

I absolutely love the game so far, and I'm already completely, and entirely hooked.

reviewText:
As taken as I am with Dragon Ball Xenoverse, I don't believe I can recommend it to anyone but fans of the Dragon Ball series. For those people... I can't recommend it highly enough.

The graphics are perfect (It really does feel like playing an episode of Dragon Ball Z), the combat is, for lack of better summary, excellent, the story was incredibly well done (Historical battles are faithfully represented, cut scenes closely mimic the manga, timeline alterations are tasteful and fit well), and Cell's voice acting is at least 30% better than in the TV show.

Now that's all well and good, but the avatar creation and character customization take the cake. Placing your hero alongside the Z Warriors is pure, concentrated childhood wish-fulfillment. The feels you'll feel the first time you go Super Saiyan are hard to describe, but fall somewhere between Boner-rific" and "Worth the price of admission".

$50 is a small price to pay to go Super Saiyan. You do want to be a Super Saiyan

reviewText:
THIS is the Dragonball Z game that every kid wanted 13 years ago, flaws and all.

The fighting system can sometimes feel a bit cheap but there's no mistaking it: you can pull off insane combos just like you see on the show, and it's so fun when you do.

There's a lot (and i do mean a LOT) of player grinding. You are meant to do side missions, improving your time and ability each time you do them, for the experience, money, and item drops. You then use the money to buy better skills, or learn them from a trainer. If it sounds tedious it certainly can be, but the combat is what keeps the game from devolving into being boring. I really didn't mind that I was grinding because the combat was just THAT fun.

This goes without saying that your nostalgia and how much of a DBZ fan you are will have a huge impact on your ability to play this game. If you loved DBZ as a kid (or hell, even now!) and you always wanted to play a fighting system that let you do the crazy stuff you see, then this is the game for you. If you are looking for the next deep/technical fighter then look elsewhere.

reviewText:
Pros
--
- Awesome Unlockables
- Decent Customization (Races, Clothes, Accessories, Combos, Powersets, Ki Attacks)
- PVP vs Friends and randoms Online with Custom Character or your favorite DBZ characters
- Compete with Friends and randoms in Boss Battles
- Entertaining filler story that interacts with Main story arcs.

Cons
--
- MAJOR COMPLAINT: Xenoverse Stability Issues
- Frequent Disconnections from Xenoverse Servers (you have to access their servers to even select your character, unless you're in steams offline mode.)
- Customization needs more Customization (IE: Hair, Changing colors of your favorite DBZ Characters outfits, detailed body style, logo creator, etc.)
- Camera angles block view in certain areas of map where enviornment is your field of view.
- Random screen tears.
- Random game crashes.
- Gameplay quests can become repeatitive and frustrating. (It's a fighting game, what do you expect?)
- $25 season pass, DLC is always a Con.

Overall Opinion:
--
About the $25 Season Pass, Please Devolopers/Publishers, go back to the roots. Include everything into the game and give it out for free. Or if companies have to make money on DLC and it worked like GTAV, where consumers had the option of purchasing ingame currency (which you can aslo make online for free), I'm ok with that as well. Either way, That keeps the hype train alive and people will continue to spend money on your hardwork. Otherwise than that, and the cons I listed, theres nothing really bad about this game that kept me from playing it.
In my opinion, it's one of the best DB games ever created. The fact that the original author (Akira Toriyama) did the story and artwork makes it even better. Recommended for the most hardcore of DB Fans.

reviewText:
This review was written after the first gameplay session that lasted almost 15 hours. I was the last person among all my friends to have the game downloaded, yet i had the most played hours in just one day XD
This game is absolutely the best DBZ game i've ever played in my life... but it has its cons, like low number of characters (but the amount of good characters and variations outweigh that).

Pros:
- Best DBZ Game Graphics!
Although graphics don't matter, this game captures the DBZ feeling so well!
- Gameplay mechanics are easy-to-learn, hard-to-master
For some reason, as i progressed through the game, i started using less complicated combos, but i should be practicing them in the future.
- Create your own character
Who doesn't wanna be a Z-warrior? and to top it off, you have 8 different variations of gender/race
- A ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•TON OF REPLAYABILITY!
The parallel quests are seemingly endless, and you'll find yourself replaying the same thing over and over again (still having fun with it) just to get that one skill or item...but you end up finding a hidden condition or something that rewards you with better stuff :D
- All-new Story
Without spoilers, i found the story really awesome (though it felt like a Time Squad rip-off xD), i loved the fact that there are 2 endings (if you defeat the final boss fast, before a certain somebody could come and aid you, you get the secret ending).
- Deep interactions, like characters recognizing your CaC's race and commenting on such, or fun interactions like Vegeta SSJ4 with Beerus
- A lot of other stuff like the Master System and such

Cons:
- Gathering the dragonballs is a pain in the butt, i still haven't gathered them all :\n- Some missions you'll be pitted against 2 or 3 super saiyans at the same time, and those mofos keep spamming their ultimate because of their seemingly infinite ki, it kinda gets annoying especially when you need to finish the quest for an item or such
- There's a bunch of glitches that happen often, though they're not that major and i'm sure they'll be fixed
- Some missing characters/transformations (although some could be understandable)
- The whole DLC ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•t...tbh i feel with those people who were waiting for reviews to see if they should get the game or not...and they had a low chance of guaranteeing a preorder" copy of the game on any platform... seriously? ssj4 vegeta for DLC when goku and gogeta ssj4 are in the game? and i found files for great ape baby in the game...that's supposed to be $10 DLC

Overall 9/10
Why? the game is way better than the whole PS3/X360 gen games

reviewText:
Great game with some flaws, still these don't prevent it from being second to Budokai Tenkaichi 3 in terms of the best Dragon Ball game.

If you want an arcade mode only where you just collect hundreds of characters (dozens, just repeated versions of the same), and all you do is fight, then this might not be the Dragon Ball game you are looking for.

Xenoverse expands the fighting genre conventions, adding many features that would make any fighting game a better game. From the freedom it allows you when creating you character's fighting style, to the many activities and types of missions you can play on your own, with friends, against them, or even with total strangers. Playing with friends is a literal Blast.

At first seems simple and botton mashy, but there is a deep combat system to master, and the fighting feels just as good as it did in Budokai Tenkaichi 3, but way more varied and thoughtful. Also there are tons of unlockables, and when you create a new character all skills and gear is shared, so you dont have to grind back again for that rare skill" you really need. In terms of lasting appeal

reviewText:
For those banking on a traditional fighter, you may be disappointed. Xenoverse feels more like an RPG brawler than your average fighting title. The controls are not overly complex and ultimate attacks are only a button push away which makes Xenoverse a very easy game to be introduced to. Giving your friends a fighting chance will not require hours and hours of one sided matches. Though one can say the combat lacks complexity, there is no denying that duking it out in matches feels fantastic. The game is responsive and fast paced.

The RPG elements are strong for a fighting game.
Customization is alive and breathing here, character creation is impressively well done for such a title and is easily 'the shining star' feature of Xenoverse. Quests are engaging and plentiful. At times Xenoverse feels more like an Action RPG / Fighter Hybrid and if you are open to this then you will be enamored by what Xenoverse offers. If you are only interested in traditional fighters, this may not be the game for you.

Pros:
-Solid and intense combat
-Amazing character creation
-Tons of customization
-Incredible amounts of content
-Stellar multilayer experience ranging from co-op to vs
-1v1, 2v2, 3v3 play
-Great visuals
-Replay Value

Cons:

-Minor bugs (these are infrequent)
-Servers have been a bit wonky (Having trouble connecting to online hub from time to time)
-Mediocre story

8/10

reviewText:
For those banking on a traditional fighter, you may be disappointed. Xenoverse feels more like an RPG brawler than your average fighting title. The controls are not overly complex and ultimate attacks are only a button push away which makes Xenoverse a very easy game to be introduced to. Giving your friends a fighting chance will not require hours and hours of one sided matches. Though one can say the combat lacks complexity, there is no denying that duking it out in matches feels fantastic. The game is responsive and fast paced.

The RPG elements are strong for a fighting game.
Customization is alive and breathing here, character creation is impressively well done for such a title and is easily 'the shining star' feature of Xenoverse. Quests are engaging and plentiful. At times Xenoverse feels more like an Action RPG / Fighter Hybrid and if you are open to this then you will be enamored by what Xenoverse offers. If you are only interested in traditional fighters, this may not be the game for you.

Pros:
-Solid and intense combat
-Amazing character creation
-Tons of customization
-Incredible amounts of content
-Stellar multilayer experience ranging from co-op to vs
-1v1, 2v2, 3v3 play
-Great visuals
-Replay Value

Cons:

-Minor bugs (these are infrequent)
-Servers have been a bit wonky (Having trouble connecting to online hub from time to time)
-Mediocre story

8/10
