reviewText:
I love this game. It's the DBZ game I've wanted for almost 10 years now! So good. The story is fun and enjoyable and the multiplayer is also great. The difficulty is high enough that you won't get bored but low enough that you can still have fun while learning the game. Some of the Parallel Quests are seriously tough!

Only down-side is that the game is pretty  grindy. You will have to replay missions many times to get all of the unlockable equipment and skills. The plus side of the grindiness is that it gives the game a lot of replay value. Additionally, since you can (after you complete story mode) make new characters while maintaining your equipment, skills, and scores, it lets you level up additional custom characters without having to completely start over (although you are level 1 again so you will have to level up!)

All of your favorite characters are available as playable characters in Parallel Quests, although you'll be required to use your custom character to complete the main storymode.

If you're a fan of Dragon Ball, this is a game you cannot pass up.

reviewText:
First off, this is an extremely good port. Other tahn the expected oddities with specific graphics cards, it runs at 60fps with no slowdown at max settings for me. The controls are responsive and intuitive for the most part. You can do keyboard controls (I don't know if you can change them because I'm using a controller) and the controller has many different options (but no individual button changing). The default controls make sense and I haven't felt a need to change it.

Graphically it looks fantastic. It looks like a great transition from the 2D anime to 3D cell shading. The voice acting is the original people from the show as far as I can tell and it's as good as it was back then.

The story is very goofy and dumb and more just an excuse to allow character creation while revisiting the big fights of the Dragonball series starting from the Saiyan saga. It also has a reimagining of various scenarios through the Parallel Quest system, which is basically just more fighting with a bit of reasoning on top of it.

The character creation is varied enough, you get slider options for height and weight (which just means how wide or narrow your character is) along with a selection of the races that have different stats and abilities. You can change the color of your hair and skin and there's a large range of colors there. You also get equipment through missions and shops and can customize your character that way too. It's limited but not terribly so, you can still get a personalized character and I haven't seen any characters similar to mine.

The online mode is extremely fun. Playing with a friend and being able to just wreck the CPU is unbelievably fun. You just do it for the Parallel Quests and can't do it for story mode, which considering the difficulty of the story missions makes you wish they had allowed it.

The game is flashy and chaotic and fun. If you liked the old Budokai games then you probably already own this. If you like fighting games and DBZ then you should get this. It's a fantastic port of the game and the online component is great when it works. Unsurprisingly, it being the launch of the game, the servers are getting hammered so there's a few problems with that at the moment but that won't matter in the future.

reviewText:
Dragon Ball Xenoverse is a pretty decent game but for the most part it's not anything special for the average dude and I can't really recommend it to those guys. BUT.. are you a Dragon Ball Z fan? 'Cause if you are, that changes everything! To a DBZ fan, this game is a dream come true! Unlike pretty much.. every DBZ game ever, this game doesn't just rehash the same old sagas. This game takes place outside of time where you revisit those sagas trying to prevent some bad dudes from changing history! You get to actively take part in DBZ history fighting alongside Goku, Vegeta, Trunks and all the other DBZ legends as your own custom guy. Finally your dream of becoming a Super Saiyan can come to fruition!

The game is still not without its faults: The clothing system is pretty limiting and you might have to end up looking like a doofus to get the best stats, the combat is kinda clunky and no where near as polished a product as you'd get from a Capcom fighter, and if you wanna become the best, it does get kinda grindy at times; but to a DBZ fan, this is currently the definitive DBZ game.

If you're just a random guy, this is just another game to you, but if you've grown up on DBZ and loved its universe, you owe it to yourself to snatch this game up and fight for the future!

reviewText:
After 30 hours, I can conclude that Dragon Ball Xenoverse is not an AWFUL game.

However, its fantastically solid core gameplay and character customization are steeped in such awful game design reminiscent of MMORPGs a decade ago. If grinding levels, key items hidden behind double RNG, and repetition are for you, then I can safely recommend the title.

Otherwise, Xenoverse is only for the most hardcore Dragon Ball Z fans blinded by sheer nostalgia. There's just too much BS you have to sift through to find the gold. If you are just a casual fan, either wait for a STEEP sale ($20 or less) or the inevitable Dragon Ball Xenoverse 2, which ideally will correct and streamline many of this game's wrongs.

I'm not really sure why the game is getting such widespread positive reviews... it's NOT a good game.  Maybe people are really excited to make their Original Character Do Not Steal" DBZ fan creations
date: so excited in fact that they overlook all the game design travesties committed in Xenoverse.\n\nGo in knowing what kind of game this is.  This isn't as straight forward as the Budokai or Budokai Tenkaichi series
recommended:
and there are frustrating game design elements at EVERY turn.

Ultimately it feels wrong to tell someone not to play this game.  My recommendation is less of a recommendation and more of a friendly warning towards Dragon Ball Xenoverse.

Buy it only if you know what you're getting yourself into."

reviewText:
Without a doubt, this is the quentessential DBZ game many have been asking for since the very beginning of mainstream DBZ games. Fun and addictive combat. Character progression and race variety. Transformations, coop, PvP, and live events. There is even a unique story for you, the player, to have your mark on the Dragon Ball Universe, and it's actually very good! I can honestly say this is easily the best DBZ game I've ever played.

I still have to complete all the bonus sagas and gain another 20 or so levels before I hit the max level, and I've already invested a lot of time into the game. This isn't even including the future content that will come from the three DLC packs, which will offer more time patrol missions (main story), parallel quests (side quests), more special moves, more playable characters, more costumes, more mentors, etc. This game is going to have an incredibly long life, as long as DIMPS continues to support it.

My only criticism is the online connectivity is incredibly unstable as of now. Sometimes it will work. Other times it won't. Luckily, you don't actually have to be on the multiplayer lobby in order to do coop and PvP with friends. That being said, it is rather frustrating to not have one of the major components of the game working as intended. Hopefully, this is something DIMPS will have sorted out sooner rather than later.

It's certainly not terrible to the point of being broken, but online stability definitely needs some attention. Other than that, if you like Dragon Ball, enjoy a fighter/MMORPG experience, and always wanted to make your own story and character in that universe, this is the game for you. Even if you aren't a fan of the show, there is A LOT of content to be found here. I highly recommend this title. Great game.

reviewText:
Dragon Ball Xenoverse is a great game and, IMO, the best Dragon Ball game.

We were introduced to character creation in Ultimate Tenkaichi but not like this. Your character is much more customizable. It allows for great variations between characters. In addition, instead of being a Saiyan, you can choose from 4 other races, including Majiin Buu and Frieza's. Your character's stats can be altered through spending attribute points and new attacks can be bought or learned. You can even change your clothes from Pilaf's clothes to Raditz's armor.

The gameplay is great. Instead of charging Ki directly, you gain major amounts of Ki by attacking and being attacked. The key to victory is timing. You have to know when to block, attack, dodge, use a super, etc. Unlike Ultimate Tenkaichi, Supers and Specials are not cutscene triggers. Each attack is different and you will have to practice to know how to use your supers. Ki is plentiful but you'll still be set back if your Kamehameha misses.

DBX also takes a new aproach to the game's story. In every DBZ game, the DBZ story is expected to be followed, leading every DBZ game to mimic the story of the show perfectly. In DBX, however, they take a clever twist on the story. Instead of following Goku's journey, you play as your customized time hero and have to travel to major battles in the story which have been altered(e.g: Ginyu switches with Vegeta instead of Goku). To repair the alterations, you must defeat enemies. People who enjoyed following the story of DBZ may want to try a different game but TBH, if you only want to follow the story, just watch the show again.

In conclusion, Dragonball Xenoverse is a great fighting game and the best DBZ game. In fact, the only obvious problems I found was that the game would occasionally crash(especially during the Cell saga) and the online servers were inactive during the time I was playing. Although, servers going down is common during releases and I don't doubt that this problem will be fixed soon.

TL;DR: DBX is a great fighting game and the best DBZ game so far. The online connection may be down if you buy now so watch out!

reviewText:
Well ok. Where should I start?
This will be a honest review and definitely not one of those fanboy or hype reviews.
No, also no Kuririn died review...

When this game was announced and it was hyped as hell I actually got interested into it.
Especially after all the bad DBZ games that have been made. Budokai Tenkaichi 3 was the last good for me and is still the best of all DBZ games of all time. I dont get it why they dont make a new Budokai Tenkaichi like 3. This would be amazing and a must buy for me. Just make it Namco. Budokai Tenkaichi 4 or whatever you have in mind. Maybe just make a cheap BT3 Remake with some new characters and Sagas like Golden Frieza. I dont even need a completely new developed game. Also do it for PC though!

Well, after that was said it should be obvious that I didnt really enjoy Xenoverse.
Yeah, I did not. It was one of the better DBZ games but none which I would like. Maybe I expected it too much to be like Budokai Tenkaichi, because its not at all like Budokai Tenkaichi. For me the gameplay feels boring. Its actually like a MMORPG. And since I dont like MMORPGs this game falls flat for me. People who like MMORPGs and DBZ will probably have the time of their life. I dont. The main story is actually well made! How it was implemented NOT. In fact you had to level up your character to do the Story. Also the difficulty is sometimes too easy and sometimes too high. The devs werent really able to make something between. Thats the burden of a MMORPG I guess. Also for me nearly all fighters played the same. There was nothing really unique to them. Beside that their super attacks were extremely boring made. Thats what I love Budokai Tenkaichi for. Every player feels unique especially with all their transformations and super attracks. It was interesting though to create your own fighter. This was one of the, for me, very few good aspects of the game. Also for some reason the armor and clothing aspect is stupid because it gives you extra stats. Like that everybody is forced to use something specific and not just what he or she likes.

The PC Version is quite good, not perfect though. The fact that any sort of Anti Aliasing is absent is horrible because the game just screams for Anti Aliasing. There is a way to force it over Nvidia Inspector with a Anti Aliasing hack". AMD users have bad luck though and have to live with horrible FXAA. Also what annoyed me to hell was the waiting times to connect to the Xenoverse server
date: even if you just wanted to play Singleplayer. This is nearly impossible by the way...\nThe devs also released several DLC packs for the movies and DB GT and stuff. Those are totally overpriced though and should have been in the game for free. Money milking at its finest. To this comes a Pre Order exclusive character. There is no other way to get this character without Pre Order. And another horrible implementation... To this comes now the dropped support from the devs. Probably they are doing Xenoverse 2 which will just be like the first. Sadly it got a trend to make always the same game with maybe a different story but the rest is the same. Naruto is one of the glory examples of this. Those games sadly developed into the same ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• that CoD is nowadays. Always the same boring crap filled with DLCs and after a few months support is dead and the next is on the line. People still buy it though. Which I will never understand. People will buy it anyway and even Pre Order to get unique characters. I will definitely not buy Xenoverse 2 and rather wait for a new Budokai Tenkaichi sort of game

reviewText:
DBXV is a mixed bag.  The fighting side of the game is a lot of fun, and controls very well compared to older DB-series fighting games.  The movements are fluid and attacks are aesthetically pleasing.  There is enough variety in creating your skill-sets to keep the combat interesting and unique.

However, the rest of the game has it's issues.  The scripting/acting in the story leaves much to be desired. Cut-scenes are laden with bugs and visual glitches.

Single-player (offline) quests run smooth enough, and don't have the netcode issues plaguing the online versions of the same quests.  Oftentimes you'll find yourself stuck in a quest, waiting for the timer to run out because an NPC failed to spawn.  Other times, your character will be stuck in-place, unable to assist your teammates.  This can happen even when it looks like everyone's latency is acceptable.  Yet, it happens far too often.

Drop-rates on items and skills are a mixed bag.  Some people farm entire days to finally get something to drop, while others will get it on the first try.  There's a lot of RNG praying involved.  Would it not be better to put the drops on the stores after you Z-rank a mission, perhaps?

The secret" goals on missions keep it fun
date: but it's difficult to coordinate with online players without using voice chat.  This is an online game - Why not open up typed chat
recommended: rather than using pre-scripted chat options?\n\nThe interface in the hub city could use some work.  But once you find where all the menu options are
hoursPlayed: it tends to flow.\n\nPvP is unbalanced
voteText:
and there are cheaters taking advantage of bugs that make them nigh unbeatable.  There is no in-game report function.

I find the experience is far better playing offline until the netcode issues are resolved.

If you're a fan of the DB series
helpfulPercent: it's probably worth playing when it goes on sale.  The character variety and fun combat will keep you entertained for many hours.  But if you're not into the series
votesHelpful: it's probably not worth your money as a fighting game."

reviewText:
So what can I say. As with all Dragon Ball games this one is best reserved for fans of the series. It's less of a traditional fighting game and more of a brawler with fighting game inspired themes. The gameplay regardless is solid and responsive. The A.I. does seem to have a few advantages over the player in single combat, being able to react and counter more quickly than human players are able even with the best of reflexes, but it forces the difficulty factor up a notch.

There is a learning curb to this game, and no luxury of a difficulty mode to chose from. Getting stronger will help with those super tough fights, which is paramount to the Dragon Ball theme. Some seem to have it better than others. I was able to plow through the story and mission modes with relative ease, encountering few road blocks on the way, whereas my friend spent a good 2 hours trying to kill Saibamen and failing... miserably.

Most everyone you'd care to see in a Dragon Ball Z game is in the roster, with few overlaps in Form based" characters. The custom characters hold well to Akira Toriama's style and overall the game looks well polished. Add in the expansive and engaging gameplay with the story it's a great game. There are some notable bugs
date:
but nothing that can't be patched in the future.

At present the games servers are marred with connectivity issues. The most negative thing I can say about the game is the programers made a huge error in the way the game format is meant to run as an MMO. To even log in you have to make an initial connection to the "Xenoverse server" which is glitchy to the max. If you're lucky you'll make it to the character select screen. From there you're lucky if you can make it into the actual game to play a mission or two before losing connection to the server and rolling the dice to see if you can get back in again. Namco games has made it public they're aware of this issue but one week since release we've yet to see any fixes yet.

For now you're best off stowing your money towards something until they fix the connection issues and make the game more stable. There is a way I discovered to get an uninterupted session but it requires a lot of luck
recommended: and doesnt persist through changing characters. Definatly keep an eye out for the fixes though and be ready to dive in. There will be many hours of fun awaiting you."

reviewText:
Dragon Ball Xenoverse is in my opinion the best game to come out since the Budokai Tenkaichi series. If you're a Dragon Ball fan at all this game is a must own.

Pros:
- Character customization is nothing short of spectacular. Pretty much any combination of styles or any race you want to be from the series is here and it's fun to customize your character just the way you want them.
- Character progression is great. Customization doesn't stop at just appearances you get to control the type of fighter you want and customize the move set to fit your play style.
- Fighting mechanics are easy to pick up and learn but at the same time have an incredibly frenetic pace that is a bit hard to master which makes for just the right amount of difficulty in my opinion.
- New and interesting story that isn't just a bland rehash of the same plot we've seen countless times.
- Tons of content and  missions to keep you playing for hours.

Cons
- Team mate AI is absolutely atrocious. Sometimes so much so that some battles come down to luck instead of skill. NPCs have two different modes, one is gang bang your opponent to the point where you can't get a hit in edge wise and the other is to stand around like faceless blithering idiots in a Bruce Lee movie waiting for their turn to get their face smashed in by the enemy. Either way they could use some tweaking.
- Hit detection can seem a bit unresponsive and wonky. It's not HUGELY noticeable but it's there.
- Shady day one DLC practices. I don't like character DLCs, I think that's essentially piecing out the game for money and it's wrong.

Overall this is the kind of fighting game the franchise has needed for a long time. The core fight mechanics are great. It's got a great hook with the character customization, letting fans create their own hero which is something touched upon just barely in previous DBZ games. It's got a great story that breathes new life into the otherwise stagnant and repetitive narrative we've seen from these games in the past. (I love the DBZ story as much as anyone BUT there's only so many times I can play a game with the same story).  You'll spend hours customizing your character, unlocking new moves, increasing your characters strength and just all around enjoying the new story and atmosphere the game has to offer.

So, going to redo this...

POSITIVES -
HOLY ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• YOU'RE A ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ING CHARACTER IN THE DRAGON BALL Z UNIVERSE AND GOKU SMILES AT YOU AND YOU CAN GO PEW PEW PEW OH ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.

Also everything else. Clothing and powers are solid, camera can be touchy but otherwise the fighting is fluid and interesting.

NEGATIVES -
I'm playing a female character. Why are you calling me a dude? I've been staring at my ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• for like 13 hours, dude. Is there something I need to know?

The game has issues but its still extremely enjoyable. The biggest problems are graphical in nature. The textures not put together and checked thoroughly enough and a lack of caring for matching up mouth movements, verifying that cutscene elements don't conflict.. It happens, its kind of a gimme.

The other thing is the character roster setup. Kind of a step back from earlier games who had the formula perfect. Lots of overlap but they don't condense the form to core characters. Not ALWAYS, at least. Frieza takes up 3 slots when, in theory, he should only take up one and have form escalations.

The NPCs are pretty poor as well. Using SSJ2 Goku, SSJ1 Future Trunks but they never use their form changes, they simply rely on their most basic super attacks and fail to coordinate or think past that. It can be a bit frustrating as you are pulling all the weight in fights.

If any of this is fixed along the way, I'll update the review accordingly. Otherwise its a very solid game, engaging and had me on it first day for 13 hours. This is a feat that is rarely ever accomplished with me as I have vidya ADD.

Long story short: Should you play this game? Yeah, bruh.

reviewText:
Dragon Ball Xenoverse is not a perfect game, but it's probably the best Dragon Ball Z game we've got right now.

The combat is simple, and fairly easy to learn. Each button corrosponds to a single action (light attacks, heavy attacks, ki blasts, etc) with little to no need to string together complex button presses or move the control stick around to do combos, sort of like a hack-and-slash game. You've also got Special moves (all of which cost 100 Ki) you can do using the same buttons while holding down the left trigger, and a couple Ultimate skills (costs 300 Ki) and an Evasive skill (costs 300 Stamina) that can be used the same way, just while holding down both triggers. Over all, combat is simple and easy to learn, but still manages to be fun, especially when it comes to mix-and-matching skills on your characters to see what works well together.

The story isn't too special, but in a way, it also kind of is. Most Dragon Ball games have us play through the same story that we all know and love, maybe with a few details changed around. But overall, it's still usually the same story. This gamedoesn't quite do that: Instead, Dragon Ball Xenoverse's story sort of picks up important things from the now-defuct Dragon Ball Online, an MMO with a lot of original ideas that didn't get to last long enough to see them properly executed. The Time Patrol returns, and your character is one of them, having been summoned by Trunk's wish on the Dragon Balls for a warrior who can help him fix up the timeline. Yes, you're exploring the story of DBZ... sort of, but the point this time is that critical moments in the story have been changed, and your job is to fix these continuity errors by correcting the outcome of battles that Towa and Mira have used their magic to change. An interesting twist that allows for newer elements without leaving the classic characters and settings behind.

Everyone gets to create their own original character for the game to use as their avatar for the HUB world and story quests, and there's a pretty good amount of customizability for your character. There are a number of races, all with their own distinct strengths, and even a character's sex makes a small difference, encouraging the player to make multiple characters to try out all the different combinations. Your character can also equip virtually every technique and article of clothing you could think of. Want to be able to use Hercule's Dynamite Kick and Freiza's Death Beam at the same time? You can do that. As long as you're willing to work for it, you can get it for your character, and there are very few limits as to what kind of character can equip what kind of skill. Your imagination really is king, here.

... Or at least it would be, if not for one little factor: The RNG. There's a large random factor to a few things in the game (NPC location, drop rates for skills and equipment, etc.) in the game, and it's far from generous. The drop rates in this game are quite stingy, and the missions are typically fairly long unless you are grossly over-leveled, so going through a 5-to-15 minute quest, only to not get anything out of it, can be annoying, especially if it happens multiple times in a row. Sadly, the rank you score on a mission doesn't really seem to affect drop rates, only how much EXP you get. Thankfully, EXP gains are pretty generous, especially if you rank high on a mission, so leveling up is fairly quick. You're likely to level up ever other mission you do, as long as its level and yours match up evenly enough. Each mission also has multiple stages" to it that can be unlocked if you complete certain tasks within the mission in a specific way. However

reviewText:
Best Dragonball game ever. Inventive story, great visuals and lots of easter eggs all over the place. The combat feels as true to the source material that you could probably get and the created character campaign portion is inventive (written by Toriyama, expect nothing less than great). The new MMO-esque social hub has replaced a traditional menu system and I can understand how it can bother someone who doesn't want to run for 10 seconds to get to a certain menu but I appreciate what they've done with it. Ultimately it all helps add to the emersion into the DBZ universe and make you feel like a character in the series and not just a videogame player. It might get more annoying later, but for now I like it. But that is not the game...that's just a social system and the game is awesome. I looked at most of the poor reviews and none of them really gave any valid reasons for not recommending this game. People whined about the game having an MMO hub world as a menu, or that the game was too hard. Or that they didn't understand where to go. ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing read the text instead of button mashing through the tutorial and then writing a poor review because you're too impatient to sit through 5 minutes of guidance. The controls are just fine, you can't custom edit the control scheme but the defaults are just fine as is. There is no problem with the target lock system if you know what you're doing and don't hit the wrong commands to switch targets. This is a DBZ fan's wet dream and it's on the mother‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing PC.

Cons- This was developed primarily for consoles so the social functionality you would expect for a PC title just isn't there. For example there is no textual chat bar anywhere, the most you can do is edit preset responses, It's easy to play wioth friends if you have them on Steam but difficult to link up with those that are not on your Steam friend list. Also, because this game has to cater to last gen consoles there are a lot of things that are limited such as loading screens between the 3 areas of Toki Toki city (the social hub world) and the destruction of environment animations disappear shortly after destruction. However the game still looks beautiful. Hopefully the next installment to this game will not be built for last gen consoles and these issues would quickly dissappear.

9/10

reviewText:
***SPOILER ALERT***

Steam is SEVERLY flawed when letting other people use your game when playing with a different account on the same computer; somehow Steam doesn't want to remember a save for a friend's use of the game, it always starts from the Prologue.

To see how this happens, share your game with a friend who also has a steam account, or in some cases with a second account you've made for yourself, and then attempt to play the game; when a friend saves the game it never keeps, the second account always starts from scratch.

(Makes it difficult to try a different species for starters without having to go from the very begining every single time. So, be prepared to have a long levelling process before you can have more than one character on the same account. The only advantage is that the Parallel Quests will all be there to help your secondary characters level quicker)

Summary:
Recommended for real DBZ fans but no one else.

reviewText:
Dragon Ball Xenoverse is in my opinion the best game to come out since the Budokai Tenkaichi series. If you're a Dragon Ball fan at all this game is a must own.

Pros:
- Character customization is nothing short of spectacular. Pretty much any combination of styles or any race you want to be from the series is here and it's fun to customize your character just the way you want them.
- Character progression is great. Customization doesn't stop at just appearances you get to control the type of fighter you want and customize the move set to fit your play style.
- Fighting mechanics are easy to pick up and learn but at the same time have an incredibly frenetic pace that is a bit hard to master which makes for just the right amount of difficulty in my opinion.
- New and interesting story that isn't just a bland rehash of the same plot we've seen countless times.
- Tons of content and  missions to keep you playing for hours.

Cons
- Team mate AI is absolutely atrocious. Sometimes so much so that some battles come down to luck instead of skill. NPCs have two different modes, one is gang bang your opponent to the point where you can't get a hit in edge wise and the other is to stand around like faceless blithering idiots in a Bruce Lee movie waiting for their turn to get their face smashed in by the enemy. Either way they could use some tweaking.
- Hit detection can seem a bit unresponsive and wonky. It's not HUGELY noticeable but it's there.
- Shady day one DLC practices. I don't like character DLCs, I think that's essentially piecing out the game for money and it's wrong.

Overall this is the kind of fighting game the franchise has needed for a long time. The core fight mechanics are great. It's got a great hook with the character customization, letting fans create their own hero which is something touched upon just barely in previous DBZ games. It's got a great story that breathes new life into the otherwise stagnant and repetitive narrative we've seen from these games in the past. (I love the DBZ story as much as anyone BUT there's only so many times I can play a game with the same story).  You'll spend hours customizing your character, unlocking new moves, increasing your characters strength and just all around enjoying the new story and atmosphere the game has to offer.

reviewText:
Dragon Ball Xenoverse is not a perfect game, but it's probably the best Dragon Ball Z game we've got right now.

The combat is simple, and fairly easy to learn. Each button corrosponds to a single action (light attacks, heavy attacks, ki blasts, etc) with little to no need to string together complex button presses or move the control stick around to do combos, sort of like a hack-and-slash game. You've also got Special moves (all of which cost 100 Ki) you can do using the same buttons while holding down the left trigger, and a couple Ultimate skills (costs 300 Ki) and an Evasive skill (costs 300 Stamina) that can be used the same way, just while holding down both triggers. Over all, combat is simple and easy to learn, but still manages to be fun, especially when it comes to mix-and-matching skills on your characters to see what works well together.

The story isn't too special, but in a way, it also kind of is. Most Dragon Ball games have us play through the same story that we all know and love, maybe with a few details changed around. But overall, it's still usually the same story. This gamedoesn't quite do that: Instead, Dragon Ball Xenoverse's story sort of picks up important things from the now-defuct Dragon Ball Online, an MMO with a lot of original ideas that didn't get to last long enough to see them properly executed. The Time Patrol returns, and your character is one of them, having been summoned by Trunk's wish on the Dragon Balls for a warrior who can help him fix up the timeline. Yes, you're exploring the story of DBZ... sort of, but the point this time is that critical moments in the story have been changed, and your job is to fix these continuity errors by correcting the outcome of battles that Towa and Mira have used their magic to change. An interesting twist that allows for newer elements without leaving the classic characters and settings behind.

Everyone gets to create their own original character for the game to use as their avatar for the HUB world and story quests, and there's a pretty good amount of customizability for your character. There are a number of races, all with their own distinct strengths, and even a character's sex makes a small difference, encouraging the player to make multiple characters to try out all the different combinations. Your character can also equip virtually every technique and article of clothing you could think of. Want to be able to use Hercule's Dynamite Kick and Freiza's Death Beam at the same time? You can do that. As long as you're willing to work for it, you can get it for your character, and there are very few limits as to what kind of character can equip what kind of skill. Your imagination really is king, here.

... Or at least it would be, if not for one little factor: The RNG. There's a large random factor to a few things in the game (NPC location, drop rates for skills and equipment, etc.) in the game, and it's far from generous. The drop rates in this game are quite stingy, and the missions are typically fairly long unless you are grossly over-leveled, so going through a 5-to-15 minute quest, only to not get anything out of it, can be annoying, especially if it happens multiple times in a row. Sadly, the rank you score on a mission doesn't really seem to affect drop rates, only how much EXP you get. Thankfully, EXP gains are pretty generous, especially if you rank high on a mission, so leveling up is fairly quick. You're likely to level up ever other mission you do, as long as its level and yours match up evenly enough. Each mission also has multiple stages" to it that can be unlocked if you complete certain tasks within the mission in a specific way. However

reviewText:
When I heard a Dragonball Z game was being released to the PC (and was going to be released in the US unlike DBZ online), I knew I had to have it. Dragonball Xenoverse is definately made for the fans of the series, but it may be a hard game for people new to the series to jump into.

Story: Bad guys are changing the history of DBZ and you have been summon to stop them and restore balance to time. Simple and fun, just like DBZ.

Gameplay: For those looking for a detail fight system like Street Fighter, Dead or Alive, Mortal Kombat will be disappointed. The buttons for combat are simply light and heavy attack, special Ki attacks, and special strike attacks. Stamina meter for blocking and dodging and ki meter for special attacks. The combat remind me a lot of a Super Smash Bro style game. By that I mean its fast pace and easy to get use to for any player.

You create your own custom character from one of several races: Frieza clan, Namekian, Saiyan, Earthling, Majin. As you do missions you level up and can put your attribute points into stats (attack, special attack, special strike, health, stamina, ki). You can change outfits, equipment, z-souls (a special trait that activate during a fight), special attacks.

The game main story mission get much harder, so you need to stop in between every saga and play a parallel quest to level up so that the next story mission is easier. Parallel quests can be played alone or with people online. Playing with friends online is where this game shines (mostly because the ally AI borders from being dumb as a bag of brick or your savior at times).

Overall if you are a fan of the game series then you probably already have this game and playing it. If you new to the series it may be hard to get into because you only see part of the main DBZ story and it a warp version of it anyway. But don't let that detour you. DB Xenoverse is a fun fast pace game that is easy to get into and much fun.

Now if you will excuse, it time to grind my character some more.

reviewText:
Best Dragonball game ever. Inventive story, great visuals and lots of easter eggs all over the place. The combat feels as true to the source material that you could probably get and the created character campaign portion is inventive (written by Toriyama, expect nothing less than great). The new MMO-esque social hub has replaced a traditional menu system and I can understand how it can bother someone who doesn't want to run for 10 seconds to get to a certain menu but I appreciate what they've done with it. Ultimately it all helps add to the emersion into the DBZ universe and make you feel like a character in the series and not just a videogame player. It might get more annoying later, but for now I like it. But that is not the game...that's just a social system and the game is awesome. I looked at most of the poor reviews and none of them really gave any valid reasons for not recommending this game. People whined about the game having an MMO hub world as a menu, or that the game was too hard. Or that they didn't understand where to go. ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing read the text instead of button mashing through the tutorial and then writing a poor review because you're too impatient to sit through 5 minutes of guidance. The controls are just fine, you can't custom edit the control scheme but the defaults are just fine as is. There is no problem with the target lock system if you know what you're doing and don't hit the wrong commands to switch targets. This is a DBZ fan's wet dream and it's on the mother‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing PC.

Cons- This was developed primarily for consoles so the social functionality you would expect for a PC title just isn't there. For example there is no textual chat bar anywhere, the most you can do is edit preset responses, It's easy to play wioth friends if you have them on Steam but difficult to link up with those that are not on your Steam friend list. Also, because this game has to cater to last gen consoles there are a lot of things that are limited such as loading screens between the 3 areas of Toki Toki city (the social hub world) and the destruction of environment animations disappear shortly after destruction. However the game still looks beautiful. Hopefully the next installment to this game will not be built for last gen consoles and these issues would quickly dissappear.

9/10

reviewText:
Summary:
Recommended for real DBZ fans but no one else.

First opinion:
Mixed feelings about this game so far. The open world is pretty useless.. the dialog is weird & awkward.

In the beginning, it is difficult to figure out what you're supposed to do. There's a map you can pull up but there's nothing to indicate where to go or who to talk to.

There's an online mode.. but you can't use it until you make progress in the story.

Fighting is as you'd expect.. button mashy. Character graphics & sound are ok.

Being a long-time DBZ fan, I do enjoy the opportunity to see & interact with the characters.. but the gameplay itself is pretty bad.

After playing for awhile:
The gameplay does get a little better & the story is actually better than expected. The button mashy feeling goes away somewhat as you gain more abilities & actually have to use some strategic thinking.. but in the end you've only got 8 move slots to use.

There are a few items to choose from at this point but they are all pretty generic fan-service items. Hopefully there are plans to add to the current inventory.

A lot of the rarer items are obtained by grinding parallel quests".. which are just basic battles with a few objectives that you must meet. There's a ranking system to determine how well you did
date: but how they sum up the scoring is a mystery.\n\nTraining under a master is pretty cool as you get to hear their voice when you fail or succeed to encourage you or call you a wreck (Vegeta)"

reviewText:
You play as a custom created character in the time patrol - effectively police to make sure that history isn't changed. It is amusing that you are summoned by trunks, who went back in time to change history. to ask you to stop people changing history. Regardless of that, you must play through the sagas from the saiyan all the way to beerus (and a little bit past that) ensuring battles end how they did in the original timeline. At the same time looking out for the people behind the changes in history.
You have amain hub which is a city divided into 4 sections. The first is the area you are summoned to by shenron. There are a few npcs scattered about, the entry to world tournament (as in an online battle), the area you use the dragonballs you can collect and the entrance to the two other sections of the city as well as the final part, the time nest.
Personally, i find the first seciton pretty redundant, as apart from the time nest and the dragonball holder, there seems to be no need for it.
The second section is the industry section. Here you will find the item shops, mix shops (you can mix z-souls which boost your stats for stronger ones that have different effects in battle depending on certain scenarios) clothing stores and a skill trainer.
The third section is the time machine station. Here you will find team registration to recruit AI or other players in multi lobbies, online and offline battles as well as online and offline parallel quests which are essentially just scenarios to play out such as defending frieza from goku or defeating every saiyan in their base, super saiyan forms etc.
You Will also find your current master in this section, the whereabouts of finding  said masters are entirely random as they are scattered throughout the  sections of the city.
The final section, the time nest, isn't technically part of the city, but it's where you have to go to begin your story quest each and every time. The supreme kai of time is also in this area, but she doesn't have a use.

Positives:
Combat system isn't too basic but isn't too advanced, so every user is able to learn the combos
RPG system and character creation allows you to make your character your way. If you want to be a melee heavy character or focus entirely on ki blast supers, its up to you.
Wide variety of moves and evasive attacks - from the classic kamehameha to broly's gigantic meteor. From whis's karate chop to trunk's shining sword attack.
Wide character roster with many variants to characters. So you can play as saiyan saga vegeta or kid buu vegeta. A saibaman or ssj4 gogeta - you can also select any of the characters to help you in parallel quests; but story missions, you're on your own.
Graphically it is one of the best dbz games out there, but that isn't much of a feat and isn't as good as it sounds as they remain faithful to cell shaded anime style - as they should.
Clothing system allows you to dress your characters up (this does come with a negative though)
Racial attributes - each race ( earthling, saiyan, majin, namekian and frieza clan) all come with slightly different starting stats and a racial attribute as well as each level up with larger or smaller stats based on race i.e. majin race gets a bigger increase to each point in health whereas a saiyan gets more of a boost to attacks.
It can be a challenging game at the start, as it is an RPG you'll get progressively stronger, but start of quite weak. This can be a bad thing if you hate grinding, but a fun thing if you'd enjoy being level 80, helping out a friend and annihilating yamcha in one combo.
Master system - you can chose a variety of masters (from hercule to beerus) to train under. Each one will give you a unique set of mission to complete and you will get rewards such as z souls and master related skills i.e. vegetas galick gun or final flash

Negatives:
Everything is completely random. Literally almost everything.
Parallel quests can give you specific z souls, other items, clothing or skills. Whether or not you get them is completely RNG. You also have bonus objectives to complete during these missions to get an ultimate finish which could help you attain a z rank. These bonus objectives have specific conditions in which to activate. However, even then whether or not  the mission will progress into the next stage of bonus objectives is entirely random. For example, in one fight you must defeat all cell jr's before progressing and taking out android 17 and 18. This is supposed to spawn cell and make the two androids get back up after you defeat them. However it doesn't always happen.
You also get time patrollers in certain missions that challenge you. Defeating them can sometimes yield a dragonball - collect all 7 and make a wish. They spawn randomly and aren't always there. Even the masters you can train under don't always appear in the city, they spawn in random locations at random times  sometimes after doing missions. You also can't just do all of their missions in a row. They'll decide when you can do the next mission. Sometimes you could do 3 in a row. Other times you do 1 and wait 10 years for the next. Or they'll ask you to get a specific z soul from a PQ which means grinding that same mission until RNJesus decides to drop it for you. Some people have claimed it's determined by how many z ranks you get in PQ's, but i failed a mission 3 times in a row and then gohans final mission was available for me, so i'm assuming it's random.

Server issues: This is an ongoing problem because they didn't expect this volume of sales and their servers cannot handle it. However unless you use the offline mode on steam you need to be connected to their servers to play. This can result in you waiting 5-10 minutes plus to log into a single player lobby to do offline quests. You can even get disconnected sitting in the single player lobby, which kicks you back to the main menu. Multi lobby is almost out of the question right now, and online PQ's or battles are quite laggy. This will be sorted out soon though, and the servers are already much more stable since release.

Clothing: Whilst the clothing is a nice idea, every piece of clothing gives you certain stat boosts or negatives. This can mean that if you wanted to dress up like certain characters you may have to attune your character to use the stat boots provided by the clothing, or lose some of your current stats. Some armour is race specific or gender specific and you have no ability to filter through saiyan only, or frieza only. You just have to check by scrolling through each piece.

This is only a minor annoyance to me and i'm nit picking at this point, but if you fail a PQ you'll spawn the same place you did if you succeed. In the time machine sector about a 20 second walk away from the quest vendors with no button to allow you to rety from failure. You'll have to walk all the way back to the vendor each time. It's not that bothersome, but it'd be nice to not always have to be in the hub, to just select another mission and carry on or choose to return to the hub

Overall, 6.5/10
There are some dlc's coming out which will add new characters and missions which i think is pretty neat, but i'll be waiting to see what they are before i purchase a season pass.
It's a good game, i've got some decent hours on it and it's fun with friends. If you're a fan of Dragonball Z, you'll most likely enjoy this game. If you've played some of the previous games, no it's not as good as the budokai tenkaichi series, but it's definitely an improvement over battle of z or UT. Though i prefer the character creation, abilities, and even graphics to an extent in UT.
If you dislike MMO grind, or want a really in depth combat system which you'll play online battles for hours as if you're on street fighter or mortal kombat, this is not a game you should buy.

reviewText:
As somebody who hasnt gotten to play a DBZ fighting game since DBZ: Budokai 2 on Gamecube, being able to finally pick up a next gen DBZ title, and on steam of all places is just perfect for me. I've been a Dragonball Z fan for as long as I can remember, and whether you are a fan or not, I think this game will be a fun and satisfying experience for everybody. The game is able to run very smoothly even on my laptop, and I rarely ever have any issues with playing it.

The only game in my library that I've played longer than this title is Skyrim, and that's saying a lot. There are plenty of things to do in this game, so it'll keep you busy for hours upon hours. The game has full controller support, so and the controls are thankfully very easy to learn, as instead of having to pull off annoying combos, you can just use the trigger buttons to access your Super and Ultimate moves provided you have enough energy to use them. I have had some issues with the game responding to my button presses and a little bit of input lag, but that might just be my computer or the graphics settings.

This game looks pretty, plays well, and is all and all a very fun game to pick up and play. My main criticisms are that sometimes the RNG is terrible and it makes trying to find masters or gathering Dragon Balls or getting certain item drops from quests rather tedious, which can sometimes make playing them feel like a chore. Another thing I would have liked to see was an option in the clothing and accessory shops to preview what you're buying. You dont get to see anything but the name and stats of the clothes you buy, so you either have to look it up online, or buy it blindly. If you dont happen to like it, your only choice is to just deal with it or sell it back for half of what you paid for it. Some quests are also almost unfairly hard, and some of those quests are ones you must get from NPC's, so you may not bring support characters or finish the quest online with a friend until you beat it once by yourself. It wouldnt be so bad if it werent for the fact that some of these involve characters that like to spam their super attacks so much you cant even move and get comboed from full health until you die, one of these quests being one where you have to fight at least 15 characters by yourself to complete it.

Complains aside, this is a really fun game, and an interesting take on the story in the DBZ universe, and I'd recommend it to anyone, especially a DBZ fan.

reviewText:
DBXV is a mixed bag.  The fighting side of the game is a lot of fun, and controls very well compared to older DB-series fighting games.  The movements are fluid and attacks are aesthetically pleasing.  There is enough variety in creating your skill-sets to keep the combat interesting and unique.

However, the rest of the game has it's issues.  The scripting/acting in the story leaves much to be desired. Cut-scenes are laden with bugs and visual glitches.

Single-player (offline) quests run smooth enough, and don't have the netcode issues plaguing the online versions of the same quests.  Oftentimes you'll find yourself stuck in a quest, waiting for the timer to run out because an NPC failed to spawn.  Other times, your character will be stuck in-place, unable to assist your teammates.  This can happen even when it looks like everyone's latency is acceptable.  Yet, it happens far too often.

Drop-rates on items and skills are a mixed bag.  Some people farm entire days to finally get something to drop, while others will get it on the first try.  There's a lot of RNG praying involved.  Would it not be better to put the drops on the stores after you Z-rank a mission, perhaps?

The secret" goals on missions keep it fun
date: but it's difficult to coordinate with online players without using voice chat.  This is an online game - Why not open up typed chat
recommended: rather than using pre-scripted chat options?\n\nThe interface in the hub city could use some work.  But once you find where all the menu options are
hoursPlayed: it tends to flow.\n\nPvP is unbalanced
voteText:
and there are cheaters taking advantage of bugs that make them nigh unbeatable.  There is no in-game report function.

I find the experience is far better playing offline until the netcode issues are resolved.

If you're a fan of the DB series

reviewText:
This game is tons of fun. It is great to be able to hop into the Dragonball Z universe that I loved so much as a child. I love the fact that you can be mulitple races. Best part is being able to get many different skills that are used throughout Dragonball universe. Here is a list of pros and cons for this fantastic game!

Pros:
-Character Creation
-Many different moves
-Tons of hours of fun
-Online capabilities (w/ friends)
-Many memorable moments get to be relived
-Decent story

Cons:
-The grind is real sometimes for moves due to RNG
-Online capabilities with randoms can be poor sometimes since not a lot of people seem to play with randoms
-Can become repetitive and boring
-Saiyan race seems op compared to other races due to super saiyan capabilities

That is my personal pros/cons list that I have came up with while playing the game. I highly recommend it to everyone, but especially those who love the Dragonball Z universe. If you would like to check out some gameplay before you make your decision to buy this lovely game, then feel free to check out the playthrough on my channel! Hope this review helped persuade you to buy this fantastic game!

reviewText:
I don't often review anything, mostly because I don't think I'm qualified to. This game, however, is an exception.
Please note that I have not and do not plan to play any PVP, so that will not be factored in here.

A little backstory:
Growing up, DBZ was one of my biggest influences and loves. I fell in love with the characters, the story, and the outrageous combat elements that made up what is today one of my most favorite anime series of all time. Naturally, when I first played a DBZ game (Budokai 1) I was very excited to see the universe I'd grown to love and be able to play it. Flash forward to now, with the release of THIS game (Xenoverse) and I couldn't be happier.

Pros:
Story- VERY much like the anime, but of course with that cool, time-warped twist. I found myself on the edge of my seat a LOT.

Characters- Not much to say here other than they're the ones you came to love (or hate in case of villains). Customization could stand to be a bit better, but overall I'm happy with what I can create in the games' system.

Gameplay- Plays much like the Tenkaichi series of games. Fly around, auto-combos, teleports, ki-blasts, ultimate attacks... you name it, it's pretty much there. A blast (buh-dum-tss) to play, and I never get bored of it. Can be a bit wonky, but overall is very well polished.

Graphics- GORGEOUS. Damn this universe looks amaaaaazing in this game. Couldn't be happier with it.

Cons:
Story- None that I have problems with.

Characters- Villains (Toma, Mira, Demigra) can be a bit too predictable or cliche, but that doesn't necessarily detract from the overall experience.

Gameplay- AI is sort of barebones, but once you get further along into the story and PQs (which are good, varied, and challenging at higher levels) the ai becomes a real challenge to deal with. Up until about the android saga and PQs 17+, the AI isn't very good. Some attacks whiff when they shouldn't, but no other gripes with attacks.

Graphics- N/A.

Do I recommend this game?
HELL YES (if you're a fan of the series).
Yes! (if you're a fan of rpg/fighter hybrids).
No. (if you don't like SOME (partly unnecessary unless you want to GIT GUD) grinds). (Diablo-esque, but a bit better in my opinion).
Yes again! (If you like gorgeous games with a wealth of content that won't leave you bored).

Overall score: As a fan of the series- 9.5/10. Very great game, well-polished and satisfying.
Objectively- 8.5/10. Good, if a bit irritating, in terms of gameplay and adaptability (at first).

reviewText:
Well here's a short review.

Pro's
-DBZ game
-Not to bad fighting system (overlooking a few op combos)
-New story arc to get involved in (as in your own character)
-Race Selection for CaC is neat with each race having different stats

Middle ground
-OK Character Customization, I wish there was alot more, but as it stands now it works for the most part you can pretty much make any character from DB into this game the eyes / hair / everything is ripped straight from exsisting characters (No Videl hair though for some reason...)
-Farming Skills and Outfits, could be toned down a bit but its not a HUGE deal because you'll be playing the game anyway.

Con's
-Fighting music is awful.
-CaC does NOT allow any real PERSONAL choices, no Ki color, no Tail (for saiyans), no hair change for female SSJ, No making your own Attack (even if it was just copy paste with a changed name and Color shader)
-Outfits, Outfits are the equivilant to equipment in RPG's they have stats and yes I would love to wear the schoolgirl skirt / top outfit all the time, but 4star outfit has +5 (instead of a +2) to my stats. Outfits should have been seperate and Equipment or more stat points should be given to fill this.
-Outfits Part2, only some outfits can be colored to your liking, all the other stuff (again straight ripped from DBZ characters) can only be its original color.
-Difficulty, some battles are extremely frustrating, others to easy, the final boss was a cake walk compared to buu and ginyu. Could use some tweaking imo.
-Roster is smaller than previous DBZ games, pretty usetting.
-Server Issues, they suck, like real hard, if your in single lobby even expect to get dissconnected every other mission and kicked to title screen, its like they made the server out of bubble gum and spare wiring.

Overall I'm loving it, I just wish there was more CaC options. 6/10 Would bang Videl (Before she cut her pony tails off)

reviewText:
I started this game without knowing much about the DBZ universe and still had a lot of fun playing it. I started off with a human character and fell in love with the whole style of this game. The voice acting is a little bit painful but I can look past that with the game-play being what it is, amazing.

I played through the story mode, with a good amount of grinding the parallel quests to unlock a few things that I couldn't buy, making this game very engaging. I didn't actually beat everything until well after hitting level 80 because the drop rate in this game was horrible, making you replay missions over and over again.

I liked everything about this game, from character customization to the story. But the poor drop rate on something that gives you a chance to unlock something that already has a poor drop rate is a little too much.

I would still recommend this game to friends that like DBZ and to those that don't because starting this game, I didn't even like DBZ all that much. Now I actually love the story of the universe a lot and this game actually helped me get into the series a lot.

reviewText:
Dragon Ball Xenoverse is great if you like anything pertaining to Dragon Ball Z. Make a Namek, make a saiyan, make a krillin. Beat up some guys and fly around. It feels good to do this, and you get new powers as you do missions. If you want all the powers and all the clothes and everything, well, you gotta grind, which is a mixed bag for people. I like making characters, and I like Dragon Ball, so this was a very good game, and I played a lot of it. Flying around, fighting, and using powers is fun. It's not perfect but it works well enough. There's multiplayer vs but I haven't done much of it and it's probably bad. The game is not remotely balanced and you shouldn't expect it to be, which is fine.

There's a lot of questionable decisions that can make things frustrating on the collection end of things. Not only are ability drops random for the most part, but also the Mentor system is random as well. You can't decide who to be your mentor, you just have to wait for them to randomly show up. This is the most annoying thing for me about this game, because while drops are random for skills, at the very least you are actually playing the game, and the skills are tied to specific missions. The DLC adds mentors but a couple of them I haven't even seen or gotten the chance to train with yet, because they show up randomly, among the pool of your old mentors too. This is probably my biggest complaint with the game.

it's good fun otherwise. tldr, if you like DBZ at all get this game.

reviewText:
Fun and Easy to get into for anyone who knows the basics of a fighting game.

I'll be sinking a lot of time into this one...

However, there are a lot of pros and cons:
The Good:
- Combat system is fun and easy to learn.
- No complicated combo strings that require 15+ button presses.
- No Directional inputs.
- Silly, wacky storyline that fits the DBZ universe perfectly.
- Diverse array of skills, stat choices and gear.

The Bad:
- Currently the servers are god awful. If you can even log in, you'll be kicked after doing a few missions.
- Convoluded stats. No explanation for what any stat does, and the only way to redo your stats is by gathering the Dragon Balls, which can take 2-5 hours to farm all 7 of (Because RNG is amazing).
- RNG. All I really need to say here. It ruins games.
- While there ARE a lot of moves, most of them don't scale linearly with your damage stat, so you'll find yourself using a much smaller pool of abilities for maximum damage.
- AIs are wonky. Your allies as AIs are borderline braindamaged, even in the storyline, and your enemies spam evasive/recovery moves like crack addicts. The only big challenge is actually landing a combo on an enemy AI.
- Unflinchable boss fights. In a fighting game about combos and locking down an enemy, it completely defeats the purpose to add enemies that cannot be flinched in an easy way. Not only do enemies become bullet sponges, but they become unflinchable and a pain in the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• to solo unless you abuse Z-Souls or items, BOTH of which form bad habits.

The Ugly:
- PvP is a mess of hackers, abusive Z-Souls and glitch exploits. I'm staying clear of this until they fix it. Like, to give you an accurate image of how BAD the hacking is right now: 1 in  3 players you meet will be a hacker in PvP. Unlimited energy. Unlimited Stamina. Unlimited Health. Because who buys a game to NOT HACK, am I right?
- The final boss in the storyline is such a huge letdown of a fight. Instead of adding meaningful or cool mechanics, they simply made him a huge, unflinchable waste of time.

reviewText:
Fun and Easy to get into for anyone who knows the basics of a fighting game.

I'll be sinking a lot of time into this one...

However, there are a lot of pros and cons:
The Good:
- Combat system is fun and easy to learn.
- No complicated combo strings that require 15+ button presses.
- No Directional inputs.
- Silly, wacky storyline that fits the DBZ universe perfectly.
- Diverse array of skills, stat choices and gear.

The Bad:
- Currently the servers are god awful. If you can even log in, you'll be kicked after doing a few missions.
- Convoluded stats. No explanation for what any stat does, and the only way to redo your stats is by gathering the Dragon Balls, which can take 2-5 hours to farm all 7 of (Because RNG is amazing).
- RNG. All I really need to say here. It ruins games.
- While there ARE a lot of moves, most of them don't scale linearly with your damage stat, so you'll find yourself using a much smaller pool of abilities for maximum damage.
- AIs are wonky. Your allies as AIs are borderline braindamaged, even in the storyline, and your enemies spam evasive/recovery moves like crack addicts. The only big challenge is actually landing a combo on an enemy AI.
- Unflinchable boss fights. In a fighting game about combos and locking down an enemy, it completely defeats the purpose to add enemies that cannot be flinched in an easy way. Not only do enemies become bullet sponges, but they become unflinchable and a pain in the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• to solo unless you abuse Z-Souls or items, BOTH of which form bad habits.

The Ugly:
- PvP is a mess of hackers, abusive Z-Souls and glitch exploits. I'm staying clear of this until they fix it. Like, to give you an accurate image of how BAD the hacking is right now: 1 in  3 players you meet will be a hacker in PvP. Unlimited energy. Unlimited Stamina. Unlimited Health. Because who buys a game to NOT HACK, am I right?
- The final boss in the storyline is such a huge letdown of a fight. Instead of adding meaningful or cool mechanics, they simply made him a huge, unflinchable waste of time.

I think the easiest method of telling whether or not you will like this game is this: do you like Dragon Ball Z? If so, you're probably going to like this game. If not, well, while the game won't set your world on fire, it does a lot of pretty cool things.

One of those cool things is the fact that, while there are heavy liberties taken, it DOES tell the basic story of the Dragon Ball universe. This is nice for newcomers, but the heavy liberties are more for the benefit of old fans, as these liberties make sitting through the same story we've been watching, reading, and playing for the last 30 years a somewhat fresh experience.

One of said liberties (that was advertised heavily leading up to the game's release) is the use of custom avatars. That's right, you can create your own character using any one of five universal races, those being Earthling, Saiyan, Namekian, Frieza Race, and Majin, and take said character throughout the Dragon Ball Z timeline, participating in iconic battles against the backdrop of an almost shameless excuse plot of time travel and interventions in the timestream. reviewText: This game is super fun.  Loved the main story as well as the Parallel Quests.   You get to create your own warrior in the Z universe!  How can you not enjoy that if you have been a fan of the series!  One thing I will note is that you will not be able to run straight through the main story.  You will also have to complete quests on the side in order to level up enough to be able to pass the story.  The DLC also add quite a bit of content to the game.  You can train under various Masters, including Beerus and Elder Kai.  The best part is that you can play online with other people.  That makes the game much more fun and you get to show off your character and its abilities to others.  After you pass the main quest, however,  there is not much else to do.  I did get about 100 hours out of it, which is plenty of time for this type of game.  Highly recommended to any fan of DBZ.  Make sure to get the DLC for extended fun!

Xenoverse doesn't even really look like an RPG, but that's what it is. It's an MMO with a fighter skin. And it's not a bad idea really. reviewText:
Dragon Ball Z lovers will like this

Those who aren't fans of the series, well... Not so much.

Now, Budokai Tenkaichi 3 was a game that even people who hate the series could love. This one sort of requires you to get a gist of the lore and story to truly enjoy. Not like BT3 where you could have never seen or read anything about the show, jump in and get a good jist of it all.

ANYWAY

Since non-fans wouldn't buy a DBZ game anyway, onto the juicy stuff

The game feels like a polished version of Battle of Z. Bringing up that trainwreck of a game is usually bad, but this game still feels like it... In the posative ways. By that I mean the lock-on, deathmatch style is back, rather than the tag-team from BT3. Also like BoZ you can revive teammates in the same way.

Like everyone else is saying, they leave you in the middle of a small, clunky city off in the beginning with little introduction of what to do, and most of the world is locked off.

The city isn't necessary, that could easily be condensed into a small menu, don't be excited for that free roam. It's just slowly running around a clunky city (what is flying)

The roster size is pretty good. Nothing like BT3's monster of a roster, but still a nice size. We get some characters that aren't even memorable, too, like Raspberry (That sounded negative... I'll be honest, I ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing love when they give us a ton of more-obscure characters. It's so damn cool <3)

You can play as a number of races, each has a small stat boost in one area or another.

















Yamcha has a fake-death supermove. Get this game, ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.

reviewText: A great DBZ game I played it to hype me for Dragon Ball Super I don't regret it but my main gripe with the game is that it is very very very grindy probably on the same level as an mmo. I would also like a hair change between normal to super sayian my characters hair didn't change and I cried for a day because I grinded for 6 Hours trying to get SSJ. But the character creation is where this game shines and FINALLY a new DBZ story instead of the same rehashed story we always get. The fighting is SUPER fun but at times it got a little clunky but it was simplistic and made it fun for 1 v 1 matches locally because you could easily teach your friends. So overall this is my favorite DBZ game Sequel please.

reviewText:
I bought Xenoverse purely for the childhood nostalgia of the DragonBall series. I was pleasantly surprised at how much fun I have had with it. The combat system isn't anything earth shattering but it is a lot of fun. The added RPG elements with gearing up, potions, and quest lines make for a great experience. The story was a typical DragonBall one, but it was fun to play through. The combat isn't particularly challenging, however there are a few frustrating fights. I haven't done any PvP so I can't comment on that side of the game.

DBZ Fan = you'll like the game
Fighting game fan = you'll like the game

I wouldn't buy it at full retail, but on sale it's a definite buy.
